reviewText: For about a decade now, the entire movie industry has survived by ripping of 70's hits and raping classic works of literature (don't get me started on stinking Baz Luhrmann). I just saw this advertised as "amazing" and the "blockbuster hit of the summer"--it's pretty sad when a copy of a copy is the best you have to offer. After all the game play, generation cell phone has some skill at spicing-up these old classics with computer-generated special effects, but there ends their talents. I think the phones attached to their heads have rotted their brains. I'm from the generation that brought you Michael and Jason and Freddy and Pinhead and Alien and Predator and Star Wars and, yes, Planet of the Apes--the list goes on and on. There is no talent or creativity in stomping over this old ground, and apparently not much effort to do better. How can you argue when the movies still have to turn to Harrison and Sylvester and Arnold and Bruce for real talent? What happens when these whiny punks run out of 70's and 80's material to steal and rehash for easy money? I think it's time to hang up and (at least try to) create something of your own.

Andy Serkis is amazing. He began this franchise as Caesar in "Rise of the Planet of the Apes." In addition, he was Golem in the "Hobbit/Ring" string, along with Professor Haddock in the "Tin Tin" series (the next two have been announced). As a voice actor, his job is to convey a panoply of emotions using just his eyes, his voice, and motion-capture equipment.

In this second PG-13 chapter of the "Planet of the Apes" prequel, we are ten years into a simian flu virus which has destroyed most of mankind. The apes live a peaceful life in the misty forests of northern California, hoping there are no human survivors. To their dismay, two dusty vehicles jostle their way through the woods, looking for a dam that includes a generator which holds the key to life in the remains of San Francisco, where many human survivors have gathered. The apes are NOT thrilled. Those of you who are familiar with San Francisco will enjoy the landmarks (not limited to the Golden Gate Bridge).

Here is part of the (huge) cast:
  * Andy Serkis ("Arthur Christmas") is Caesar, the lab experiment grown to the Alpha male of this new generation of apes. He believes in education, peace and mercy. He has taught his fellow apes Amslan, the American sign language.
  * Jason Clarke ("The Great Gatsby") Malcolm is the first human captured by the apes. He does NOT expect recognizable human language, a sense of justice, nor the imposing presence of a thoughtful Caesar. "They could have killed me!"
  * Kirk Acevedo (Lots of TV) is Carver, the trigger-happy lamebrain who refuses to listen to reason and tests Caesar's resolve for nonviolence. I really liked what happened to Carver.
  * Keri Russell ("Austenland") Ellie is a doctor who is also Malcolm's significant other. She comes along on that exploratory trek "just in case."
  * Gary Oldman ("RoboCop") Dreyfus is convinced the dam will generate enough electricity for San Francisco to recuperate. He has no qualms about killing apes: "They're animals!"
  * Karin Konoval ("Rise of the Planet of the Apes") returns as Maurice, the orangutan who serves as a teacher to young apes. He emphasizes "apes do not kill apes."
  * Kodi Smit-McPhee ("Romeo and Juliet" - 2013) Our youthful Alexander discovers that he and Maurice have something in common: they both love books.

Director Matt Reeves has spent a king's ransom on excellent Computer Generated Imaging; personally, I would have cut at least 30 minutes from the 130-minute running time, but the story of human bungling and its impact on an untested ape population, kept me involved to the very end. They included scenes from the first prequel in this new series, although I had to smile at that amazing battery in the abandoned video camera which still worked after 10 long years; I want one!

Those of you who are familiar with San Francisco will enjoy the landmarks (not limited to the Golden Gate Bridge). Just fast forward your DVD from Amazon if you don't care for all the CGI.

What an exciting and thrilling blockbuster! I was worried about this film. This was the 8th add on to the Planet of the Apes series, second to the reboots. So this Is a sequel and an eighth movie. I expected that it would feel a bit stretching, but it isn't. In fact, Dawn of The Planet of The Apes' main purpose Is to show another side of these super apes and to set up the story for the next film in the franchise.

This isn't just about fighting; in fact, fighting scenes, even though they are epic, take very little part of the film. There is romance within humans and apes families, sometimes, the apes can act funny. Dawn of The Planet of The Apes is thrilling and kept me at the edge of my seat the entire time! Also it has a story line no one expects!

The original Planet of the Apes book is about humans that went to a planet ruled by apes. When they come back to Earth, the same thing happened to our planet. The reboots, (Dawn of The Planet of The Apes and Rise of the Planet of the Apes) are pretty much prequels. So, Caesar leaves civilization with his ape friends while the human race almost goes extinct due to a deadly virus. The remaining humans struggle for power. Will they be able to find a new source of power or will it be up to the apes and their leader to decide the humans' fate?

For me, this is a fantastic addition to the series. They don't try too hard to make it too action-packed and cool looking. The apes look extremely realistic and I really like that. They include some scenes from Rise of the Planet of the Apes which helps to pull it all together nicely. The action and fighting even has some stuff from the original 1963 Planet of the Apes book! The director made it a perfect length and, in fact, this is the first time I've seen what I would call a "trailer" movie (a movie that looks like an hour-long trailer for the next one in the series) that is entertaining and includes a surprise ending.

My favorite scene is when we see a small group of humans working on the power station. When they wake up, the youngest is sitting with an ape that acts as a teacher to young apes and is very loyal to Caesar. The kid gives him a book and reads along with him. It shows how well they actually understand each other and how alike humans and apes are. It shows friendship and how two creatures of different species can be friends.

This film has some violence and intensity so I recommend it for ages 11 to 18. I also give it 5 out of 5 stars for fantastic graphics, a well planned story, excellent cinematography and stupendous acting.

Reviewed by Gerry O, KIDS FIRST! Film Critic. For more youth reviews, go to kidsfirst dot org.

I enjoyed this film. Parts of it seem to me to be parables, such as the destruction of most humans and the ability to speak, etc that apes acquired was the result of the misuse of science, a warning to us. Also, there were people among the apes and among the humans who wanted peace, but the opportunity failed because of a few stupid people/apes that followed a single person/ape, another warning. Even when this problem was resolved, another arose, the issue of blame and refusal to forgive. In a sense these examples are parables of what is wrong with human nature.
The second main part of the film, the first to most people, was the action. There was much of it.
I thought that Andy Serkis was great as Caesar, the leader of the apes. I was amazed how with all that was done to make him look like an ape, he and the other "apes" were able to express emotions in their faces and actions.
This movie wraps up the perfect trilogy!

The Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is my favorite of the three films that tell the story of Cesar.  The human characters from the Rise of the Planet of the Apes are all gone, but the new humans are new and unique and not simply replacements.  At times the story is intense and it is easy to forget that these are talking apes, at least momentarily!  It's easy to see that the Planet of the Apes stories can continue and with parallel universes or time travel, the latter element already firmly established in the original film series, many more original stories are still left to be told.

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is the second film in the recent Planet of the Apes reboot franchise.

The plot is set 10 years after the first film, Rise of the Planet of the Apes. The intelligent apes have formed a colony in the forests outside San Francisco, while humanity has been almost wiped out by an epidemic which started when the apes escaped the laboratory where mad scientists kept them prisoners. When a group of heavily armed human survivors return to SF, the stage is set for a bloody conflict. Soon, both apes and humans split into factions, for or against a war. The ape leader Caesar wants peace, while his rival Koba opts for the destruction of humanity.

Bizarrely, Koba is supposed to be a bonobo  in reality, bonobos are the most peaceful of the great apes! I wonder what prompted the scripwriter to project his hominan aggressions onto the hippie ape? And yes, Koba was the nom-de-guerre used by a certain Dzhugashvili before he became more famous as Stalin

Dawn isn't particularly interesting or good, and feels illogical on a number of levels. Only two stars for this production.

The best thing about Rise of the Planet of the Apes is that it sets up Dawn of the Planet of the Apes.  The best thing about Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is that it sets up War for the Planet of the Apes.  The trilogy gets better as it goes, both story-wise and visually.  But unlike a lot of trilogy second acts, Dawn works on its own.  Its basic weakness is that what could have been a really good first contact story, a tragedy of miscommunication and mistaken assumptions, is instead a simpler, less interesting story driven by bad guys.

Ceasar has moved into the Muir Redwood Forest outside of San Francisco.  The apes haven't seen any humans in 10 years, but it appears that more than that amount of time has passed.  The cities have fallen back to nature- vines and plants are taking over the concrete buildings and it appears that war has devastated large parts of San Fran.  We find the apes living in beautiful peace, learning how to read and write.  Maurice, the adorable Orangutan is the loving teacher who scrawls, "Ape no kill Ape" on the rock walls for the young pupils to learn.  All this comes to a sudden end when a group of humans bumps into a hunting party of apes and one of the people shoots an ape.  The people are looking to repair a dam that is near the ape's home but must cross their territory to get to it.  This causes instant conflict and distrust because the humans had no idea that the apes had 'evolved' to such intelligence.  The story rolls from there.  Love the CGI, makeup and special effects on this installment of Planet of the Apes.  "Rise" was too reminiscent of the Charlton Heston version with the hokey masks/make up and the last one looks too dependent on CGI- looking almost like a cartoon.  'Dawn' has just the right mix of technology to make the apes look real.  The storyline is tight, moved quickly and moved the heart.  You'll cheer for individuals that are apes and humans as the story teaches us about good and evil.  Andy Serkis is wonderful as Caesar- I love the technology they used to create his face- it looks just like him.  Toby Kebbell is outstanding as Koba- he's the kind of vicious we love to hate!  The movie is fun, engaging and ok for the whole family.  There's violence, but not gory and in your face.  No overt sexuality, so great for the whole family.  Not for very young children as they will be upset by the death of both apes and humans.  Young teens are fine, however.  Enjoy!

My favorite film in the rebooted Planet of the Apes series. This is close to a perfect movie. Andy Serkis' work as Caesar is unreal, with the apes standing front and center as the main characters. The CG lends a credibility to these characters that surpasses the believability of the original films' costumes and masks. The only weak participant in the film is Jason Clarke as Malcolm. While every other actor is turning in phenomenal performances, he's just...there. I don't know, his acting skills are put to shame by his co-stars. Luckily, the apes matter much more in the film, and it pays off. This is a fantastic piece of work that I recommend to anyone. I think it's much better than Rise of the Planet of the Apes, and fairly better than War for the Planet of the Apes. It's the best in the trilogy and deserves respect as a piece of cinema. I still love the original from 1968, it had the best twist I'd ever seen, and it's still a great movie, but I didn't feel for the characters as much as I did in Dawn. It's truly amazing.

Dawn of Planet of the apes is a great followup to the surprisingly exceptional Rise of Planet of the Apes film.  The plot literally picks up right where the last movie ends and I love how the director chose to show how the virus spread around the world infecting every city and country.  The cast is excellent and the movie has a strong story and plot just like the last film.

You don't need all the World War Z gore to show how quickly a civilized society can be wiped out and be put back to the dark ages.  Caesars colony of apes is surviving and thriving in the U.S. west coast wilderness.  Just the fact that the grizzly bears have came back from extinction in California show progress somewhere.  Nature finds a way.

We are never given much knowledge of the surviving humans are they immune to the Simian Flu Virus or was it like Omega Man with Charlton Heston where a vaccine was created and the last survivors injected themselves.  You never find out the film leaves that open ended.  The majority of the surviving humans are civilians not military.  They are just trying to pick up the pieces of their lives and start anew.

What the movie focuses on is the hatred left behind for the apes like Koba who were abused by humans and unwilling to forgive them.  Koba stages a coup to rally the apes against the humans and eliminate them.  Caesar struggles to maintain control and keep the apes civilized in the face of this adversity.  The film is strongest when it comes to Caesars own son Blue Eyes where you see his thoughts on humans change as well.  The film offers you glimpses of hope with the scene of Alexander and Maurice bonding of what kind of peace there could be between the two species.  I kind of wish the film would have spent  more time on Caesar telling of his own childhood with humans he cared for and loved in the first film mainly James Francos character Will Rodman to his son Blue Eyes.  Maybe they added that in the special edition.

My only gripe with the film is how quickly Caesar recovers from a machine gun wound in less than 24hrs.  He never grimaces in pain when fighting Koba in that skyscraper high rise so you don't really buy his injury watching the film.  Caesar would be almost doubled over in pain and exhaustion from fighting Koba.  But at the end he is standing strong and tall like he never broke a sweat.  This is the only part of the film I felt they didn't get right everything else flows very well.

In the end Dawn is a very good film just like Rise.  The reimagining of the Planet of the Apes films are very well done and you will enjoy all the personalities.  I would rate the film a high 4 stars.  I still think Rise has the better story, but Dawn is a strong film keeping the franchise rolling into War the final film in the trilogy.

I put off watching this for a long time because I felt it would be too heavy. That ended up being true but I do not regret watching it.

By heavy, I mean like Gladiator, a pretty intense movie that is very well done but takes its toll on you (because it is so well done). By contrast a light movie would be something like transformers, where you just go to see stuff blow up and don't care about any of the characters or if any of them die.

Rise was a good slower-paced lead-in to this movie. Dawn picks up two years after that with the apes minding their own business in the woods just north of San Francisco. Caesar is leading a rather large band of apes and they have their own little village with baby apes and everything. They say they haven't seen humans in a while and wonder if they are all just gone.

Of course, in the next scene, a band of humans stumble upon them and want to just take what they need. They still view the apes as "animals" and some even blame them for the "Simian Flue" that all but wiped out humanity. One human thinks that just going in and killing a village of sentient beings isn't really a cool thing to do. Despite his and Caesar's best attempts to keep things civil, conflict ensues (due to butt-heads on both sides).

Caesar is an amazing character played by amazing mo-cap actor Andy Serkis. How Serkis and Reeves can convey exactly how powerful (strong, compassionate, and intelligent) a being he is, while hardly talking is just awesome.

Side note, I just saw War last night and I cannot praise the people enough that were involved in these movies. While Rise was a fine movie, I really think that Matt Reeves really raised the bar with his two sequels.

My impressions upon watching this film were partly based partly on the first installment of  "Rise of the Planet of the Apes" . I usually  rate a movie as to whether I will watch it over and over  again, or watch it once and put it away. This is a one time deal for me. I give it three  solid stars for production value and acting, specifically by the Ape characters.  I found the human actors annoying at times and the human lead, the nice guy, irritating and wimpy. The story was slow and monotonous. Rise of the Planet of the apes was original and held my interest throughout. I've watched it several times and each time enjoyed it." Dawn" sort of moved along slowly and made me wonder if maybe they should have moved in different direction with the story line. Nothing too original. The humans being human and the Apes in turn acting as bad as humans. As with most films made today, they seem to dumb the movies down for the masses. By not making  it too complicated they fill the theaters and make their money.

Not as great as 1968's "Planet of the Apes," but "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes" and "Rise" before it are better, in my view, than any of the other 60s-70s movies. I actually enjoyed Dawn more than Rise  primarily because I'm not much of a fan of James Franco. Dawn does a great, short, neat job of laying to rest questions viewers might have about the fate of people in the first film.

Some of the characters  the idiot brutish human drone, the brutish conniving human leader (Gary Oldman, doing much the same thing he did in "Book of Eli)   are predictable. And there are serious plot weaknesses (why do all these post-apocalyptic movies have old technology that is made to work so easily?), but 3D quality, overall acting, story, and design more than make up for it.

An incredibly naive plotline that totally ignores human evolution...it took humans about two million years to harness fire, and another million, more or less, to domesticate the horse...and these super simians did this in a couple decades? I am willing to suspend my disbelief for the sake of a movie like this, but I refuse to swallow it with a large gulp of stupidity...and what is with the apes shooting automatic weapons? Where are they carrying their extra ammunition? In their bare butt cracks? It's this kind of nonsense that makes movies hard to swallow...BTW, I absolutely loved the original canon of Planet of the Apes...watched all five movies in one sitting when I was about twelve or so... time travel and its inherent conundrums were one thing...total acceptence of nonsensical garbage is another...great CGI, but little else to recommend this...

Great Movie! One of my favorite reboot(?)/prequel(?) series.

The 21st century has seen multiple film franchises rebooted.  Probably one of the best so far is the new Planet of the Apes.  The first one, Rise of the Planet of the Apes, is probably the best film so far by James Franco, was the Hollywood breakout film for Bollywood star Freida Pinto, and another epic performance by British actor Andy Serkis.  With such a great movie, the expectations for the second outing of the franchise were high, and this film met it.  Unlike the first film, which is primarily about the journey of one ape, Caesar, living among humans, this film is about the uneasy coexistence of two societies, ape and man, that degrades into an all-out war.  The movie starts out slow, with glimpses of the ape society living in the Redwood forest outside of the Bay Area of California.  Then comes a violent encounter with a group of humans that slowly escalates the violent tendencies in both the human and ape society.  The rest of the movie is a series of character studies, looking at how the proponents of peace counter the proponents of war in both the human and ape societies.  The film ends with Caesar barely holding onto power among the apes, and foreshadows the third movie as about all-out war.

Excellent sequel to a movie that I considered to be very solid. The post apocalyptic setting drew me in right away and was immediately more interesting than the previous film. It's a much darker and grittier movie than the first, but there's still some light heartedness and tender moments to enjoy.

There's a few too many forgettable side characters but luckily we get some very strong and memorable leads. Andy Serkis, Jason Clarke, and Gary Oldman are all really great. The first act is flawless. The second is a bit slow at times and even though it's predictable, you still want to see it play out. The last half hour is nonstop action and is sure to entertain and it brings everything together with a satisfying ending. Looking forward to the next sequel.

'Dawn' stars ex-Patriots wide receiver Wes Welker in the lead human role & CGI apes in pretty much all the other roles.  There are a few other human characters, but none of them are relevant at all.  There are basically four relevant ape characters (Caesar, the elderly warrior Koba, Caesar's son, and Maurice the Orang.).  The motion-capture CGI is excellent in this movie.  Sure, the characterizations are predictable as hell (ie: the bad guys are ugly, the good guys are noble etc), but hey that's American movies for you.  We all know what character is going to have what ending in the movie.  Certainly Koba is more ape than Caesar is.  Oldman's appearance amounts to a cameo.  Even though there are only five characters in the movie, the CGI more than makes up for it.  The apes riding horses?  Not so believable.  Well, most likely it's Wes...

'A TREMENDOUS AND EXCITING SEQUEL'
'Caesar' and his followers have built their own compound in the forests beyond 'San Francisco' over the
past decade.
Mankind is in decline they have been ravaged by a pandemic,the cities have all but been laid to waste,
the peace between man and ape survives as long as they stay apart.
After an incident close to the Apes compound and brief meeting between Man and Ape, 'Caesar' who
understands human-kind warns 'Malcolm' (Jason Clarke) and his team to stay away from the forest where
he and his followers live.
There is an element of the Apes that crave war against their once captors, only the logic of their leader
prevents it.
The people living within the city boundary's have become desperate, they have little or no power-source,
in the forest there is a 'dam' which could generate the power they need, but will 'Caesar' permit a human
presence close by.
'Malcom' who had been in the party involved in the earlier incident seeks consultation with 'Caesar' to try
and reach an agreement to allow a small team to try and get the generator running,if an agreement can be
reached there will be no need for war, 'Caesar' cautiously agree's on the understanding that the humans do
not carry weapons.
'Caesar' (Andy Serkis) wants to give mankind a chance to co-exist but knows how frail an agreement with man
can be, he just hopes.
'Koba' (Toby Kebbell) has no trust of humans and takes it upon himself with a few others with similar views to
find a warehouse where the humans have a large stock-pile of weaponry, 'Koba' knows that it is more than
enough to wipe the Apes out if used against them.
Meanwhile back at the Dam 'Caesar' watches over the human teams progress, however because of the action
taken by 'Koba' trust is wearing thin, the prospect of war becomes even closer.
'Koba's' betrayal will change the course of history, can 'Caesar' re-take control before it's too late or has the line
already been crossed.
This is a sprawling and exciting epic that lays the grounding for what is yet to come, the film will draw you in from
the outset, with some terrific action sequences and an underlying will from both 'Caesar' and 'Malcolm' to maintain
the peace between them.
Brilliant and Eye-Popping Special Effects Throughout, a spectacle to behold indeed.
Impressive in both 3-D and Blu-ray'
Special Features -
* Audio Commentary by Matt Reeves
* Journey to Dawn
* Andy Serkis - Rediscovering Caesar
* Human and Apes - The Cast of Dawn
* The World of Dawn
* The Ape Community
* Move Like an Ape - An Artist's Medium
* Weta and Dawn
* The Fight for a new Dawn
* Deleted Scenes with optional audio by Matt Reeves
* Exodus - Gods and Kings Trailer
* Exodus - Gods and Kings - Sneak Peek
* Stills Gallery
(Special Features are in 2-D)

Better film as a follow-up to the first film.  Both stand alone as stories but it makes a difference if you know the original film story.  Dawn's splits it's point of view between ape and man, but humanizes the apes to a degree with story and action that lines blur.  It is not an ape homage but presents both sides with their own needs, bigotry, family and political structures.  Good action and special effects, including the apes which were far removed from the stiff latex masks  of the early films. Intense warring and shooting segments but for older children could spark interesting topical debates on family movie night.

Like its predecessor, this newest film in the franchise also surpasses my mediocre expectations. Despite another uninspired plot which is wholly predictable, the movie succeeds on the merits of its visuals and performances. While the humans are all solid, the CGI apes are all beautiful to behold, and emote powerfully and gracefully in their various expressions and body language. The film opens with a novel look into the apes world, a wordless peak into nascent simian civilization which is far more enjoyable than the boilerplate fistfights and shootouts of the back half of the film.

I loved the originals.  Part of what was great is that it was an original idea and that humans weren't animated with CGI which made the link between the two worlds believable.  PLEASE STOP USING CGI, spend the money on better writers hollywood.

I found the talking apes hard to believe, they weren't convincing enough. I think it would have been better if the human actors had to use sign language too in order to have some continuity in the story line. I'd have to say this is my favorite primate movie of all time aside from that one where Clint Eastwood plays baseball with a monkey or something. This one had less baseball, which was fine because I didn't really anticipate a lot of baseball. If I had been I think i would have given it 4 stars. I'm curious where the monkeys got their face paint and why they found it necessary to do that.

Went to the theater not expecting much, "maybe a good fight scene, a lot of noise and action." Came out stunned; at the facial expression animations, the actual content of the human AND ape characters, and the implications/messages present throughout. This movie totally blindsided me.

Much more to offer than being another monkey movie.

Andy Serkis is "Caesar", a genetically modified chimpanzee raised by humans. As the alpha of a group of apes infected with a brain altering chemical, they live hidden in the Redwood forests for nearly ten years as a global plague decimates mankind. As surviving humans begin to skirmish into the forest, the apes are compelled to defend their territory, leading to conflict that could change the fate of both species.

Recomendation Level: "Should see it at least once."

Just because the main character isn't human doesn't mean it's okay to use tired old plot clichs. Obvious betrayals, obvious weaknesses, and obvious plot developments might be brand spanking new to the ape with the stone-age mentality, but the audience for this movie is modern-day humanity. We've seen this stuff a thousand times before. I was bored the whole time because it was all so predictable. And I don't mean the ending, which had to be what it was. I mean all the tired, worn-out steps a thousand stories have taken before it. The fragile wife with the newborn was my first clue, in just the first few minutes. Well, maybe the irredeemably idiotic human with the itchy trigger finger was my first clue, and the wife and baby were just a disappointing confirmation that I wasn't watching anything more than a movie made by some guys overly thrilled with their CGI capabilities.

You want to distract me from your CGI, you need A) an actual plot, B) the Avengers, or C) lots and lots of pretty explosions. This film had none of those things. It treated me like I had never seen a movie before in my life, holding my hand through obvious developments and reveals, just in case I missed them.

And it had no explosions at all. Okay there was one, but it wasn't foreshadowed properly and it made no sense and smacked of no character development. It was stupid and doesn't count. Don't watch this one.

We've probably all had at least one of those moments when you have nothing to do and browse the channels to see what might help you pass some time. Sometimes you find a movie and, at the end, wish you could reclaim the 2 hours of your life. I anticipated having that experience when I decided to watch a couple of minutes of Dawn of Planet of the Apes. A bit more than 2 hours later, I was left wondering why this film had absorbed my interest. Without imposing any spoilers, it is a socially relevant film that explores the misconceptions we might hold and the regrettable behaviors that might result. As the film blended great technology (as another reviewer commented, the CGI was astoundingly good), a good escape into fantasy, and a poignant message for our times, it was far more interesting than I had anticipated. I don't think we'll recall this film as one that revolutionized film, but there aren't many we remember that way. But I credit the everyone involved in this film for taking a premise that seemed contrived and dated, and turning it into a truly interesting film.

***This review may contain spoilers.***

Chimpanzees and other primates image as mischievous, comical, banana-loving cut-ups has been shattered. As recent studies have established, primates share at least 98% of our genetic code and also share humankinds penchant for killing and eating meat and violently squabbling with others for food, mates, and even territory.  Add to that the fact that the average chimp is at least five times stronger than the average man, and you realize that the post-apocalyptic simian society portrayed by Dawn of the Planet of the Apes (hereafter Dawn) may not be an acid-trip fantasy at all.  It just may be an imminent terrifying reality.  Maybe those who advocate granting (or have even already granted) chimps and orangutans full-fledged protected human status should reconsider.

Dawn begins 10 years after the end of Rise of  The Planet of the Apes (hereafter Rise) after the mentally-enhanced apes led by Caesar (motion captured again by Andy Serkis) fled San Francisco to the safety of the Muir Woods (replayed in a montage at the beginning of the film).  They have established a basic treetop village society, subsist largely on deer, and, though capable of speech, mostly communicate by sign language.  An epidemic simian flu has eradicated the human race  or so the apes believe since they haven't seen a single human in 10 years.  However, when a human hunting party stumbles upon a small group of apes and one shoots and wounds an ape named Ash (Doc Shaw), the apes investigate San Franciscos semi-decayed ruins and realize a sizable group of human still survive, led by rational, conciliatory, peace-seeking leader Malcolm (Jason Clarke) and more impulsive, belligerent, and ape-loathing leader Dreyfus (Gary Oldman).

The reason apes and men have mutually avoided each other is because San Francisco has had enough fuel supplies to support a quasi-civilized existence.  But the fuel supply will be depleted within 3 weeks and the only source of alternative power is an electric dam situated in ape territory.  Malcolm and his wife Ellie (Keri Russell) a former CDC nurse and her son by another father, the artistic Alexander (Kodi Smit-McPhee) manage to gain an audience with the deeply distrustful Caesar to get permission to re-start the dam, which Caesar grudgingly grants, provided they finish within 3 days and bring no weapons.  Malcolm complies.

Just as the sensible, live and let live Malcolm and Caesar complement each other, vengeful, reckless Dreyfus finds a match in Koba, a confidant to Caesar, and a fiery, bitter, aggressive human-hater because of the painful experiments to which human scientists subjected him. So, paralleling Malcolms and Caesars efforts at a truce and dtente, and even Alexs literary relationship with the orangutan instructor Maurice (Karin Konoval), is Kobas efforts to prove to Caesar that the humans cannot be trusted.  And in one of his forays into the city, Koba finds just that proof  an armory stockpiled with guns, ammunition, and war machines.  Nevertheless, Caesar continues to trust Malcolm, so Koba dangerously takes control of things by first shooting and apparently killing Caesar.

He then learns to strong-arm and intimidate some followers to grab some of the guns and launch an assault at the human refuge (the former stock exchange, I think) to kill and enslave both humans and apes sympathetic to humans.  Koba then ensconces himself within a tower.  Fortunately, Koba only wounded Caesar; Malcolm and Ellie locate him and dress his injuries and help Caesars wife Cornelia (Judy Greer) recover from giving birth to Milo.  They even manage to free Kobas prisoners (both ape and human) and regroup at Caesars childhood home in Rise.  Malcolm agrees to buy Caesar time to confront Koba at the tower, but Dreyfus has installed plastic explosives within the tower.  Also, since the dam has successfully powered up, Dreyfuss gang has even managed to establish contact with the outside world  namely a military base up north ready to fly down and help.  Can Caesar reconcile with Koba and keep the fragile peace?  Or have Dreyfuss and Kobas shameful actions doomed everybody?

Dawn, in its blatant but still sober and powerfully effective way, demonstrates the chaos that ensues when anyone (human or ape) abandons reason, harmony, brotherhood and diplomacy and gets caught up in fearful, deadly intolerance.  Dawn magnifies this intolerance through its use by Dreyfus and Koba, whose fear and vengeance have caused indiscriminate death and brought them below the lowest human or ape.  In Kobas case it is even worse because, as both Rise and Dawn argue, the primates were poised to supersede and be better than the humans because, as one of Malcolms supporters comments, they combine human intelligence with their natural agility and strength that don't need energy sources and other human comforts.  Caesar thought so, too.  But with Kobas fall, Caesar grimly admits how alike humans and apes, for better and worse, really are.  So when we witness the fires, explosions, attacks, shootings, and assaults both humans and apes in Dawn commit, we might be exhilarated, but we shouldnt.  Instead, we should be sad at a mutually lost opportunity.

I am a huge fan of The Planet of the Apes series, and loved the flick before this one. So I waited and waited for this one and when it came to theaters we were right there to check it out. I was so happy when it turned out that I may have actually liked this one a bit more than the last, which I loved. After watching this one I cant wait for the next.

Years have passed and the virus has spread killing off most of the humans. Cesar and his tribe are still out in the woods outside of San Francisco living peacefully, until humans resurface. They are looking to get to a  dam to try and get power back to the city. The only problem is the dam is in Ape territory so a war could be on the horizon. The only hope of surpassing that outcome is to try and work out an uneasy alliance, if egos from both sides can be checked.

This is without a doubt an excellent film. From the writing to the acting to the direction and look everything works wonderfully together. This movie takes everything that worked well in the first film and upped the ante. The acting of course is wonderful and that is talking about the entire cast. The effects and soundtrack as well are perfect. Honestly I cant say enough about this flick. For special features you get all kinds of behind the scenes features and a great commentary which I loved. This is a great film and a wonderful addition to the Apes films.
I purchased this DVD for my collection, I love it.

Awesome movie!

Spoiler warnings*******  Movie was very painful to watch and such a disappointment.  The sequence of events were unbelievable and the story had no real purpose either.  So the apes can talk and they come en mass early in the movie.  So at that point when they have the perfect opportunity to talk - they don't?  They just let the apes walk away with a simple exchange of "your home and our home"?

What I really don't like is lazy story telling and to me this was very lazy story telling.  So to us humans, you would think that the armory would be the number one most important resource - because we all know that other humans would be our worst enemy.  We are our worst enemy now.  The armory would have been heavily guarded and more than likely in the middle of the compound, not guarded by a 1/4 dozen men and far from the compound.  Even if the apes could have gotten the weapons - they would need to learn and understand how to reload.  Humans that have never touched weapons would not readily know how to do that.  Yet these weapons never need reloading obviously.  And on full auto (which modern army weapons are not - they are set for a maximum of 3 round burst unless otherwise modified) they would miss a great deal. But no, these apes have really good aim, even though they are not aiming and just generally pointing at full auto.  Geez.

Even really healthy apes can't keep up with a vehicle - so follow the humans would last for maybe 1/2 mile before they lost them, see simple things like in the movie should have been thought out.  Very little was thought out is what I'm trying to say.  The director or creator or whatever decided, ok we need for this to happen how we go from A to B to C makes no difference, and it does.

The plot itself.  What about it? At least in the original series the "Law Giver" maintained a series of laws "such as Ape Shall Not Kill Ape" even when the astronauts landed thousands of years later - here that goes straight out the window.  Calling Koba "not an ape" makes no sense either.  Rise was a much better movie.
I found it to be hilarious at times. Other than that, meh.

The modern retelling of this story is an enjoyable romp through current concerns and conceits. Contagious disease has replaced Nazis as the Hollywood "bad guy." Scientists are chastised for their willingness to risk a Faustian bargain in pushing biological research into forbidden areas. Character development is adequate but the plot is more than a little trite. Animal rights activists and leftists who hate European culture will revel in the stereotypes. Still it works as a rainy afternoon's entertainment that the entire family can enjoy -- from 6 to 80. Apes are portrayed as the equal of humans -- in morality and social organization as well as intelligence. Are apes to be seen as the avengers for the evils of European colonization?

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes follows directly from the excellent and exciting Rise of the Planet of the Apes.  The movie, which details two cultures (the isolated but developing ape culture led by Caesar and the isolated and defensive human remnant), doesnt play nearly as much with our sympathies for any of the main characters, ape or human, like Rise did so well.  It certainly tries to, though, as the wary Caesar goes through his own family woes and suffers a political coup, but he has too much power within his own culture to generate as much sympathy as he did when he was the vulnerable victim, the displaced underdog who rose up and overcame.  In Dawn hes at the top of the food chain so to speak and while power is wrested from him temporarily he recovers it in the most human fashion of all and thus becomes more of what he never wished to be: human.  It all makes perfect lyrical and social sense but honestly its a bit disappointing and fails to satisfy especially with the fight finale that felt like pure Hollywood overkill.  The humans fare little better in generating our sympathies.  They are divided up into the liberal/ open group who are desirous of helping the apes as well as helping themselves and the conservative/ closed group who have weapons ready to blow any threat away.  The films political statements notwithstanding, Dawn does manage to capture an idealized social order within the evolving ape culture that is naively enticing, and cultural origins and history enthusiasts are likely to appreciate the thought that went into this aspect of the films story.

While still a worthy addition to the franchise with great mo-cap performances by Andy Serkis (Caesar) and maybe even moreso by Toby Kebbell (Koba, Caesars first Lieutenant) I cant help but wonder how this movie might have turned out if they removed all but perhaps one or two of the humans, putting them into the awkward position of being captured by this new society, and seeing this society develop and change by being threatened from within more than being threatened from without by the larger and specifically more aggressive human culture.  Lets face it, for those who have watched the movie, Koba may not have been completely right but his attitudes and actions toward the larger part of humanity were prescient.  Or maybe thats just me taking the apes side.

No question this outing in the franchise is worthy of all the praise heaped upon it in these posts, and I agree with most so I will only comment here on something technical that was very annoying.  I took this BR disc to more than one player and display thinking that the problem might be my system, but no, it followed the disc.  I found that the convergence of the subtitles was way off; my eyes/brain couldn't converge them properly and it was so bad that I wound up having to close one eye when the subtitles appeared so I could read them.  I had no problem with the 3D with the movie itself, just the subtitles.  In fact, the 3D depth was so realistic that at one scene I remember saying outloud to the others in the room, "Damn, THIS is why I love 3D!"

Subtitles are a separate file on BluRay so it could just be that they were not authored correctly, I don't know, but it does get minus marks in the technical department for this glitch.  I have no idea if this was just a bad disc that I got or if anyone else has experienced the anomoly. Let me know if you have.

That said, it was a small negative that barely impacted the great affection I have for everything about this film -- (oops, not "film;" digital).

This is by far the best of all of the modern "Ape" films that have come out over the years since Y2K's "Marky Mark & the Planet of the Apes" premiered as a reboot.

 Set after the events of the previous film, Caesar is an intelligent ape who runs a colony out in the woods of tribal Apes living on a post apocalyptic planet Earth on the other side of the bridge away from the human being survivors.

 The two worlds interact by accident where the humans who need to make a repair on a dam accidently get caught & captured by Caesar's Ape militia team.  The worlds both go into chaos as one good scientist tries to bridge a friendship and alliance with Caesar and his Ape tribe, while an evil sinister Chimp decides to manipulate the Apes to go to war against humans with plans on world domination.

 Two thumbs up and a B+ for this version of "Planet of the Apes", hope to see more sequels in the future. "Why Cornelius!"  -  "Get off me you hairy Ape!"  - "Damn it all to Hell!!!"  Lol

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes (2014). Rated PG-13. Running Time: 2 hours, 10 mins. Directed by Matt Reeves. Written by Mark Bomback, Rick Jaffa, Amanda Silver. This is the eighth movie in the series. Returning: Andy Serkis, Terry Notary, Karin Konoval. Since the huge rampage on the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco and Caesar let go by Will into the woods, the virus has spread around the globe. Many people have died. There has been no communication. It is 2026. The Apes have formed a colony in the woods. They are able to walk on two legs. They think and can learn some words. Some, like Caesar, are able to speak. Caesar has a son "Blue Eyes". Cornelia has a new baby boy named "Milo". Maurice, the orangutan, asks Caesar if he misses humans. It has been 10 winters now and they have not seen any humans in 2 winters. They think the humans are gone. That is about to change. Also in the cast: Nick Thurston, Judy Greer, Jason Clarke, Gary Oldman, Kirk Acevedo, Kodi Smit-McPhee, Keri Russell, Enrique Murciano, Lombardo Boyar. Option of languages: English, Spanish, French. English Descriptive Audio. Option of Subtitles: English, Spanish. Extras: Andy Serkis: Rediscovering Caesar. Gallery. Theatrical Trailer. Sneak Peek of Exodus: Gods and Monsters (2014). Theatrical Trailers. In-film advertising: 76 gas station. Filmed in Campbell River, Golden Ears Provincial Park, Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada. New Orleans, Louisiana. San Francisco, California. I really enjoyed the heart in this movie. Well written. Like the scenes where Caesar was back in the house he lived in with Will. Too bad James Franco did not make a new appearance. Did Will die from the virus or will he appear in the next movie? Planet Of The Apes (1968) [HD] (1968). Beneath the Planet of the Apes (1970). As science fiction movies go, this is powerful storytelling. I was quickly caught up in the characters, both human and ape. The first film of this rebooted series told a very engaging story itself. I was very pleased that "Dawn" upped the ante that much more. As with the original series, this one continues to force us as people to consider our own personal moral compass in regards to how we, as a dominant species, truly would react to NOT being the dominant species. It calls into question our humanity, compassion, fears, hatred. Pretty much the same things that we question about our fellow man every day of our lives. These aren't movies about intelligent apes that threaten the existence of man....These movies are about us.

Second installment of the series and very well done. Cesar has set up his colony of apes deep in the forest outside of San Francisco while the human population has been devastated by a disease that most believe was caused by the primates. Of course they are an easy scapegoat but since no one has seen them for many years, there is no conflict. Until a team of explorers goes into the forest looking to restore the generators of a damn that will bring electricity to the people in the city. Unfortunately they come across Cesar's people and the trouble soon begins. Cesar has an affinity to the humans while some of his followers despise them because they still remember being caged and experimented on. The struggle comes from within their own as well as from the a few among the humans who want to somehow get along with the apes. Two completely different species that have so much in common yet so far apart that they will always have trouble no matter how much they want to get along. There is a battle for supremacy in both the ape colony and the human one with each blaming the other while Cesar tries desperately to hold on to his family and his rule. Even the humans have their own battle for leadership, whom ever wins will find that they have not really won at all. In all it is a very good movie and I am looking forward to seeing the 3rd installment in the Planet of the Ape series.

A decade after the events of Rise of the Planet of the Apes, the ape-ocalypse is in full swing. The apes have built a primitive community in the hills outside of San Francisco, where they hunt and gather and speak in sign language. They haven't seen any humans for two years but that changes quickly. Two friends go fishing. As they are walking back they run into a single human male who panics and shoots one of the apes. More humans show up and try to ease the situation. The gunshot is heard by the apes, too, and a bunch of them show up and start shouting "GO!" at the humans. The humans leave but they can't stay away. They are running out of fossil fuels in what's left of San Francisco and want to repair a hydroelectric dam that is near the apes' home. Malcolm, leader of the humans, begins a tense and precarious negotiation with Caesar, leader of the apes. The humans back in Frisco want power at almost any cost (and they do have a lot of weapons); the apes in their community want nothing to do with humans. Can we all get along or will there be all out war?

The movie is very tense and exciting, filled with action and complicated themes and ideas. The apes have a law that no ape kill another ape, which of course gets broken during the course of the movie more than once to great effect. Member of both the ape and the human communities look on the others as lesser beings and as fair game. The leaders work for a more nuanced approach to the others, hoping to preserve peace and well-being for everyone involved. The moral and political tension is just as high as the action tension. Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is a thoughtful and exciting sequel well worth watching.

(This review is for the 3D version.)

I'm sure that Charlton Heston is rolling in his grave over this film.

After all, he was once the spokesman for the NRA, and he also starred in the original "Planet of the Apes" franchise.  So, I'm quite sure that he wouldn't appreciate a reboot of his beloved series, especially in a modern PC-mess-of-a-world.  But if a reboot must be done, he would at least argue that guns should be OK while doing it.

But for a film that is so anti-gun, it sure has guns.  Lots of them.  There are handguns, there are shotguns, and there are even machine guns.  Even the monkeys have guns.  Heck, even one ape on horseback is even a two-gun shooter!  (One of the funniest scenes in the film, by the way.)  And this is quite surprising really in one of the most liberal cities in the world, San Francisco, or "The City" as people like to affectionately call it here.  It's quite funny that the writer and director obviously wanted to discuss the dangers of firearms while simultaneously using them so much themselves.  I did laugh quite a bit about that hypocrisy.

But I laughed quite a bit about some other things, too.  Caeser's baby boy being born, obviously borrowing from "The Lion King" from a while back, and borrowing even more from the whole "Jesus Story" from surely a much earlier era.  And I laughed quite a bit about the whole can't-we-all-just-get-along message as well; I mean, after all, humans aren't that far removed from apes -- we sure act like them quite a bit, which ironically requires us to own handguns ourselves for protection -- so we should feel a common connection, I suppose.

But still, I guess that almost 200 million US dollars were spent creating this film, and it shows.  I recorded this off of the DirecTV 3D channel -- the only 3D channel that's left on that satellite provider, unfortunately -- and I wasn't disappointed, at least by how good it looks.  I tell you, CGI effects are becoming so good, it's getting hard to tell what is real and what is not.  It makes me think that maybe NBC doesn't have to ever bring back Brian Williams; heck, the network could just create a virtual version of him, a virtual version that doesn't lie or at least only "bends the truth" as he might argue.  At any rate, with this film, the 3D really adds to the experience, especially in the forest scenes.  But 3D really shines in a skyscraper scene late in the film.  I have a fear of heights, and I felt real Vertigo while watching.

Hopefully the next film in the reboot isn't so anti-gun, or at least doesn't pretend to be so anti-gun, while promoting them so much at the same time.  It's like going out for lunch with someone who says that she's a vegetarian, but then eats a chicken sandwich, arguing that "chicken isn't really meat."  (This is actually a true story about a truly hypocritical situation and a truly hypocritical person, so I just had to throw it in.)  And I'm sure that Mr. Heston would agree with me, if he wasn't so busy rolling in his grave.

When I saw Rise of the Planet of the Apes I was afraid that I would miss the tradition of humans in makeup playing the apes since I'm such a big fan of the original films but I was blown away. The performance capture really worked thanks to excellent performance by Andy Serkis and some very talent CGI artists. Seeing Dawn of the Planet of the Apes I was afraid that I would not like it as well as Rise but I was wrong. The thing that makes these films work is that they are written by people who have obviously taken great pains to learn about and understand ape behavior. They've also done an excellent job of walking that tight rope between instinctual behavior and the ape's recently acquired intelligence. Taking place 10 years after the first film, we see the progress of intelligent apes still struggling with what's inherent in them, how they've learned to survive as non-indigenous creatures, and the psychological effects of their past experiences with humans. We also see the angst, fear and prejudice of humans struggling to rebuild following the decimating simian flu. Is it a perfect film? No, but it is a worthy addition to the Planet of the Apes legacy.

The "Monkey Planet" series seemed to have grown into a dead-tired cultural cliche.  The original "Planet" - better than Pierre Boulle's meandering slapdash novel - had degenerated into a shlock genre, bottoming in the silly 70s TV series and Halloween regalia.  I expected a trashy revival, but I have to admit so far I'm wrong about these "new apes."  They should become the defining face of the ape saga.  (Though the debut under Charlton Heston will forever remain one of the great films, thanks to its shattering conclusion.)

In this No. 2 the apes have followed their Darwinian ascent by hunting, domesticating animals, and family collectivity.  They are also engaging in politics. Unity against an external foe clashes with personal and value dissent within the simian fold.  We see the apes living as Indian-like semi-noble savages, until seriously provoked by foreign "discoverers."  The apes of course possess an invaluable resource that said trespassers must have for love, money, or genocide.  The parallels are obvious and down-to-earth - none of Boulle's space and time-travel setup.  But the movie retains Boulle's sense of compassion and dignity in struggle: this is the same author, after all, who gave us "Bridge Over the River Kwai."

The most intriguing aspect is its portrayal of ape politics.  The wise, conflicted lover of peace and family - Chief Caesar - is challenged by the treacherous renegade Koba for ape leadership into war.  Their all-too-human descent from life-saving friendship into mutual death-hatred is gist for many a night-time college head session.  Even Koba is given his due as a victim of "humanity" scarred for life in body and soul.  Perhaps the screenwriters knew that this name was Stalin's original revolutionary nom-de-guerre.

I hope that in the final war for planetary supremacy, the third installment does not devolve into Ramboesque posturing - as this series is about apes evolving into men, not the reverse.

I have to say that not a single film this year has surprised me, in a good way, as much as Dawn of the Planet of the Apes.  I have nostalgic love for the original films, because I remember watching them with my father, but other than a few catch-phrases, some interesting visual choices and that nostalgic feeling, I cant say that the Apes films are really all that good, and the sequels are atrocious.  The Tim Burton reboot was disgustingly awful (and my theater memories of that debacle still make me cringe).  Then they decided to reboot this AGAIN, this time with the incredible Andy Serkis and James Franco (whos arguably incredible, too).  I was NOT about to spend money to see that movie.  I don't care who you have in front and behind that camera, I do not have a great relationship with those apes and I don't really care to try to work on it.

I divorced them as soon as I walked out of the theater on July 27th, 2001, and since then Ive moved across the country, changed my name and pretty much wiped their existence from my memory.

I hate when films I have no desire to see because Im convinced Ill hate them turn out to have great reviews and legions of fans (a lot of whom were surprised they enjoyed it) and so then Im forced tosee it for myself.

Now, I liked the reboot.  I did.  I didn't love it.  I found some of it to be reaching a bit, some of it under-thought and the conclusion to be a tad underwhelming, but overall, it was a serious (and I mean SERIOUS) step up from that Burton nightmare.  I wasn't ready to commit to anything, but I was ok with hanging out a few times.  Now that Ive seen Dawn of the Planet of the Apes, Im debating a marriage proposal.

Like, Im seriously thinking about going all Elizabeth Taylor/Richard Burton with this franchise (I really hope you get that reference).

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes takes a lot of gimmicky movie plotlines and weaves them together.  We have the talking animals, the not so subtle racism subject, the post-apocalyptic world and the trope about how humans are their own worst enemy, and yet it does it so cleverly that it doesnt matter.  I ate this up.  I mean, this world created here is so rich, so vibrant, so real, so honest, so human, so believable and understandable and relatable and just authentic that you feel so IN THIS from the minute it starts.  The way that they take the prejudices of man and ape and make them two fold adds a layer of truth and honesty (no one is innocent) and the brutal climax feels so genuinely felt that it leaves the audience literally breathless.

The ensemble works very well with the material given, from the human actors to the CGI ones, with Andy Serkis taking the character of Caesar to another level, and Toby Kebbell completely owning this movie with his savage take on Koba.  Clarke anchors the film well (better than I thought Franco did), and the cast of distraught humans feels authentic, feels grounded in the material.

The film may visually thrive because of the brilliant CGI work here, but it also relies heavily on Michael Seresins astonishing cinematography.  The only other film to produce as many single shots of beauty this past year was Under the Skin.  Whether it be the apes leaping from tree to tree, or the rain drenched stampeded towards the human compound, this film is remarkably lensed.  Giancchinos score is tonally appropriate, and Matt Reeves direction is on it, point for point.

One of the best genre films to come out in a year bursting with genre films (and good ones at that), Dawn of the Planet of the Apes takes this franchise to a place I never thought it would go; the modern era.  For a film that is steeped in a concept we are all familiar with, whether weve seen the original films or not, this film feels as fresh and as new as they come, and the undeniably poignancy of the script never feels overbearing or tiresome but feels honest from start to finish.

I watched this on a plane trip to Europe and I was enthralled. I was trying to be quiet at first then noticed that other people were making the same hushed exclamations I was. I peeked and noticed that all of the people making the noises were watching this movie. I bought it with no hesitation when I got home and enjoyed it with the rest of my family. We all gave it five stars so that's positive reviews from an adolescent, two adults in their late thirties and early forties, and three teenagers from 14-18. Awesome job.

I don't get it.  Apes don't have vocal chords or a voice box.  How can they talk?  I don't care how smart they are, how can they talk??  They don't have opposable thumbs.  How can they fire a weapon?  Or ride a horse?  And where did they get the reigns and saddles for the horses?  It's not like they're lying all over abandoned San Francisco, nor is there material to make them, which they couldn't do even if there was, 'cause they don't have opposable thumbs!  Where'd they get hundreds of domesticated horses in the first place?

As for the humans, if they were worried about the ape army in Muir Woods, why not just block off the north end of the Golden Gate Bridge, instead of giving the apes a free pass through the obvious choke point??  And why keep the armory so far from the living area?  Why not just put all the guns and rocket launchers in the middle of the compound, away from angry apes, where they can be of some use and not fall into ape hands (that do not have opposable thumbs)??  And if you are going to put the armory far far away, why only have two people guarding the entire thing?  Two drunk idiots at that?  Two drunk idiots who KNOW the whole reason for the armory is to protect against super-intelligent hostile apes, then proceed to treat the worst one like a brain-dead carnival monkey?  At the end, why blow up the concrete tower when doing so did absolutely nothing to hurt the ape army?  And by the way, if there's a human army and soldiers coming from the north, why did it take decades to get them to help?  Seriously, the rest of civilization formed a mobile army, and no one thought about checking up on SF until they got a phone call?

Other than that the plot holds together real well.

Like its predecessor made in 2011, Dawn of the Planet of the Apes (2014) is a kind of Hollywood movie that you find pretty entertaining as long as you can suspend disbelief. A virus (the Simian Flu deadly only to human) spreads throughout the whole world exactly at the same time when the same disease makes the apes intelligent. I7m not saying this is scientifically inaccurate; I just think it is too convenient.

Once you get past that part, Dawn of the Planet of the Apes becomes interesting because of one character: Caesar (motion-captured by Andy Serkis, as great as ever), a chimpanzee and leader of the apes. Ten years have passed since the global pandemic, and when the humans are thought to be extinct, Caesar encounters Malcolm, a human asking him to give permission to repair a dam located in the woods.

Though most of the supporting characters are cardboard types, and action sequences are those of typical Hollywood blockbusters (except that participants are mostly apes), Caesar remains very interesting as a charismatic leader whose leadership is tested when he has to learn a lesson: humans are not necessarily (and not the only) enemies.

Best film of 2014. No question. I was not a POTA fan coming in to "Rise", as it was never an appealing franchise to me, but "Rise" captured my attention. When I read the storyline for this film (prior to its release) I wasn't convinced it would meet my expectations. However, it was the most thoughtful and intriguing script I watched on the big screen all year. It takes a lot to create a 2+ hour film, primarily CGI, that actually matters and has substance.

The only reason these films aren't winning awards is because they are wrongly billed as action movies and released in the "blockbuster" months of summer. I think these films deserve to be released in November/December, as serious and thoughtful dramatic films that happen to have some great SFX and a bit of action throughout.

Andy Serkis is a genius.

This could have been so much better. Good sci-fi has to be believable, and most of this just wasn't. Anyone who has ever used an automatic weapon knows that spraying and praying with your bullets consumes vast amounts of ammo; not a single monkey had an ammo belt on. And at the rates of fire they were protraying, there ammo would have lasted about 5 seconds and they would have been out. Additionally, the humans were made out to be kind of on the dim witted side. Things like not posting guards around such high value sites such as the bridge and the armory were pretty glaring errors in the story. Man has reached the top of the food chain for a reason; were pretty smart and resilient creatures. Also, the humans would have moved the armory behing there locked gates due to it being such a high value asset. So it is the little things like this which prevented this movie from being truly great. But I'm sure the folks in Hollywood could give a s*** what I think!!

This movie is a deep meditation into the nature of violence and the interconnection between man, ape, and the world around them both.

"Rise of the Planet of the Apes" was great, especially the first half, so I had high expectations for this movie.  However, "Dawn" was disappointing, other than the special effects.  If you like "action" movies you might rate this higher (there's some shooting and explosions, etc.), but for character development and plot, this was weak.  Even the music was lacking here, compared with "Rise" which had great music.  With some tweaks, "Dawn" could have been a lot better than it is, but ultimately it came up very short, very unsatisfying for those who enjoyed "Rise".

For example, in this movie Koba is a main character, sometimes hero, sometimes villain - but it's not entirely clear why his villainous side seems to take over.  And Caesar's return to his former home was clumsily done, could have been a lot more interesting.  In this movie, Caesar is supposed to connect with Malcolm almost as strongly as he does with Will and Charles from the first movie, but it seems forced and less believable.  And so on.  Ultimately it's nice to see Caesar from "Rise" here, but it's almost like one of those "reunion" movies such as "Return to Mayberry", nice to see those old characters, but it's greatly lacking overall.  Hopefully the next of this series will be better.

I enjoy all thing related to "Planet of the apes" so I was going to like this movie regardless if it worked or not.  Most of my questions about the film are "what if" questions.  In RISE in the back ground there is the news report about the "the ship that left earth."  It's referring  to Talyor leaving earth only to come by later to find earth controlled by apes.  So would the third film be Taylor returning to earth? If so how far in the future would it be?  In the original version the apes speak perfect English and wear clothes.  Would the apes of this version be that like?  Is Caesar's son in the new version Cornelius? If the film is set in San Francisco, will Taylor's ship return to SF or end up near New York? Because in the original films the apes never moved past the "Forbidden Zone", so is the the Golden Gate Bridge the marker for the new Forbidden Zone? If he they make a third film it will be fun to see what direction they take his story

What makes a "B" movie is not the budget, but how that budget is put to use. As always, this loses a star for using CGI at all. It's not that this film is bad, it's just not that good. It still gets 4 stars, (just barely), because I am a huge fan of the franchise, but really should lose one more, if not for the abuse of CGI, for the story itself. It lacks the caliber of performers and writing the franchise is so well known for. it appears to follow the Apes saga storyline pretty well, but that's about it. It's Watchable but it's difficult to accept as anything but an apocryphal chapter to the series. It certainly is NOT worth full price so I waited until it was available on Redbox.

Although the use of prosthetic make-up and well made sets and miniatures may seem archaic to some, they had a depth and warmth this film lacks. In the original series, Roddy McDowall was instantly recognizable as Roddy McDowall, and as a fine actor to boot. Moreover the performances were either that much better , or the writing was - or both, as to make this "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes" pale by comparison to earlier works. It's not a bad idea here, it's the execution that is flawed.

Had the producers taken the time and made the effort to put this project together properly, it would likely have been quite a movie. As it is, it will hardly become an iconic classic the earlier Apes films are to this day.

My opinion regarding the use of CGI in film has not changed in 30 years - it's not gonna change today. If practical effects are harder to do, too dangerous to do, too expensive to do - more than they are worth... write around the scene or do the WHOLE thing as a book - simple. If for no other reason, all the wonderful, talented, FX people, model makers and set designers the industry was once known for, may never work again...that's just not right. For instance MUCH of the background scenery generated by CGI in this movie could have been shot against a well made backdrop, or hand drawn and painted , frame by frame.

Oh, this one was good! The ongoing, and latest remake of,  the Planet of the Apes, has gone all out by adding a new twist!  Instead of trying to just do a simple copy of this obviously unforgettable story, this "The Dawn of the POTA" has gone into a new direction! The concept of making a POTA movie that takes place BEFORE the famous -the epic beginning- of the very first movie staring Charlton Heston, but, AFTER the Rise of the Planet of the apes, where Cesar leads the uprising of his abused kindred apes; this was a stroke of genius! So instead of just a "remake" with better cinematography, it's a whole new spin altogether! THIS POTA shows HOW the actual war started that led to the final (and unwanted) confrontation that sets the stage for the start of the whole phenomenon of this iconic film. It ties in timeline from the fall of man, to the splashdown in the future. Great movie! Great concept.

A very nicely done tale that touched my heart. What does it mean to be human? It means that we can learn and remember, and the treasured emotions we feel when we remember motivate our future behavior patterns. More than our use of language and our opposable thumbs, it is memory and emotion that makes us human. In that sense, Cesar is as human as any of the other characters in this film, and we can identify with him and want him to survive and thrive.

It is a great movie with an engaging story and beautiful special effects. It gives more realism to the apes and the classic sci-fi story of the planet of the Apes. I strongly recommend watching the "Rise of the planet of the Apes" movie which is the first of the series. Nonetheless, the story of this movie is developed in such a way that you are able to understand it without having to see the first one, but you'd have a greater appreciation for the storyline if you see the initial events that brought the story to the current situation.

Spoiler alert from here on: Caesar, an ape raised by a scientist and born from an ape that used to be subject to cognitive experiments for drugs to enhance brain function becomes the leader of the apes that have been exposed to the same drug (let's call it neuro enhancer). The neurologic enhancements are transferred to their descendants and the new born apes are intelligent, evolved and able to communicate. But one of the old apes that have been subject to torturous experiments in the laboratory wants revenge by subduing the human race instead of coexisting with them. This unchains a serious of events that leads to the war between the remaining humans and the intelligent apes.

At this point of the story, humans were mostly exterminated by a virus developed in the same laboratory that created the neurological enhancing medication, but the apes were immune to the virus and the medication designed to enhance human neurological capabilities backfired by becoming a lethal, self evolving, virus in the human body.

I will just get right to it--this is on the short list of the very best big-budget films that I have experienced the in past decade (others would include The Dark Knight and Cloud Atlas). Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is an absolutely incredible film. Intense action imagery, breathtaking intimacy, very thought-provoking. The apes are very real characters, every bit as much as the humans. This is not the makeup-and-symbolism novelty of the original Planet of the Apes films (or the bizarre Tim Burton remake) but a serious scenario being played out believably from the world that we inhabit. Yes, this is science fiction and requires the viewer to accept as fictionally realistic the catalyst that set these events in motion in the previous film, Rise of the Planet of the Apes. That film was a slow-burning setup; this one is the aftermath, as the flames return ten years later. The story will presumably develop more in future films, but this one is the "hinge chapter" and it is fantastic in both theme and execution.

For whatever reason, this film seems to have some passionate critics. To each their own. For my money, though, there is absolutely no question in my mind that this is the best of all the large-scale films of 2014. No competition. There have been several such good films this year, but this is the great one.

If you enjoy thoughtful science fiction, deep examination of humanity (and no, I am not saying that the human characters themselves are deeply-sketched on the whole; that is not the point of this film), brooding atmosphere and unforgettable imagery, then Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is a rare experience. Highly recommended.

Better than the first film (Rise of the Planet of the Apes).
The drama here is centered on the apes due to actions of the humans as opposed to the other way around from the first film.
There are twists that work very well, and the ape-dialogue throughout with subtitles work very well--the body language communicated helps with all the emotions presented.

The landscape, cityscape, and ruinscape settings are all beautifully shot. They worked for me.

I am shocked by how good this movie is. Seriously, I went in thinking that this would be a neat little sequel to the first installment. The entirely new feel of this new Planet of the Apes universe becomes apparent within the first 10 minutes of the movie. The post-apocalyptic settings, the rugged survivalists, the very well crafted CGI-apes, the dialogue (ape language included)... all of it exceeded my expectations. I'm actually excited by the prospect of the third installment, slated for summer of 2016.

The reinventing of this cult sci-fi franchise has truly turned Planet of the Apes into a real story and character driven drama. Not to mention probably some of the most incredible special effects in the last 5 years.

We all know where this story is going to go so yes, it is very predictable. However, from beginning to end you will be completely awestruck by the brilliant story writing, character development and pretty much everything else that goes along with this film. Bringing another wonderful actor into this film in Gary Oldman was great right off the bat, but everyone else picked to play their roles did a fantastic job. That includes Andy Serkis reprising his role as the digital ape leader Caesar. What I loved the most was the communication between the apes and how their use of sign language engaged the audience with such beauty. The film portrays so many kinds of human emotions as well as makes a major statement on the topic of war. As a whole this film is fantastic.

Forget the fact that this is based in a cult classic sci-fi film, because you will never guess when it comes to this wonderful sequel as well as its predecessor. I am very excited to see if they will complete the story in a whole new way for a whole new generation because these are just flat out great movies.

I so hate what has happened to the whole Hollywood movie industry and its horrible drive towards immorality, while at the same time it's productions are of such great acting,visual talent and creativity. The fact remains that as the public at large continues to buy into and support the movies that are pre-dominantly R, PG-13 and PG rated this is never going to change! So I am relegated to Turner Classic Movies and other Old Movie Channels, and even then I have to be careful for any produced movie made after the mid 1950's. Hollywood has used the "Boiling Frog" method to such a successful degree that most movie goers today are immune to all the godless morality that is being promoted on the screen or for the most part these most recent generations look forward to the immorality and think of it is as great fun.

This is a remarkably well-done continuation of the franchise. The pandemic introduced at the end of the previous film is played out, the few humans remaining are facing an inevitable depletion of resources, and - from the look of it - only the truly ruthless and nasty survived. What starts as an expedition to check on a hydroelectric solution to the end of petroleum fuel for generators turns into The Conflict, resolution of which takes a little over 2 hours of (mostly) engaging film time.

Given how many films in this franchise are pure crap, it's a pleasure to see a well done story. Recommended.
