Although I loved much of the CGI, I had some problems with the sameness and muddiness of many of the animal crowd scenes. I don't know what it is, but computer animators still have not gotten the hang of an animal's hind legs. This is in every CGI movie I have seen. In this movie the same problem was consistent with the apes, the horses, and the wildebeests. Each time the secondary CGI animals were all the same color with not much depth and sometimes no weight. That bothered me a bit but it's a small thing.

Cesar's facial expressions however, are second to none. His face was kept recognizable from movie one to movie two. He is easily distinguishable without the directors making him white or scarred or wearing a funny hat, or any of the obvious cheap tricks so often done in movies. I found myself rooting for him despite the fact that he is fighting against us.

In this movie the apes are in transition when it comes to dress and language. It seems they take longer to begin to talk and use few words when they do. Cornelius is still a long way off.

I had to keep remembering that these movies are made with the end in mind. I asked myself if the apes are going to win. Then I remember: of course they are. After all, we are moving up to the original POTA movie which is thousands of years into the future.

I love these two movies as much as I love the Lord of the Rings and Hobbit movies.

Really good movie! I like rise of the planet of the apes better, this one has a sequel fill to it. But I must give you some history first as to why I think that. I grew up watching the 70' version of Planet of the Apes. And when Tim Burton did the 2001 version with Mark Walberg I absolutly loved it! because that one has the most Sci-Fi feel to it, and is more true to the 70's version. But I must say the  "Rise of the Planet of Apes" I give 5 stars to because of the great storyline and CGI is outstanding! the musical score is brillant, and I love that Jhon Lithgow is in it! it does start out slow, but really brings this new generation into the world of the Planet of the Apes. I forgot that 2001 was so long ago to our younger viewers, so to them, that version was the "old" one. I heard that the 2001 version never made enough at the box office to continue. (Although I waited for the sequel) they now bring out "Rise of the Planet of the Apes" and "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes". Which has nothing to do with the 2001 or 70's version. But rather a new beginning, that is raw, and brings the new viewers up to speed. I really like this one too, I can't wait for the "monkeys" to make it to outerspace.... and I await a sequel:)

I actually found this movie to be a bit disappointing. It was very slow at the beginning, and mind you I love drama and I love foreign movies so I don't mind subtitles, I just found it rather lacking in keeping me interested. I actually had to stop it and watch it the next day because I was falling asleep. I was disappointed because I actually enjoyed the first movie and a couple of the originals.
The movie starts with you seeing how a virus has swept away most of the human race. The apes who are lead by Cesar,  have all learned to sign in order to communicate. Some of the apes even talk. When humans actually arrive it's because they are looking for a way to restore power to their camp (downtown San Francisco?). The apes' community is smack in the middle of the power grid (of course).
You soon realize that there are good apes and bad apes ( hey just like humans!), and that a coup is about to go down since helping the humans is not on every apes mind.
To make a long story short, there is in fact a coup and all hell breaks loose.
What I liked about the movie was that it is actually about the apes, humans are a side note really. The humans are all pretty much caricatures and they are there to help move the ape story along and not the other way around.
What I disliked about the movie was that the CGI got worse as the movie progressed. At the start I actually found the apes very realistic, but by the end at the last battle it seemed like you were watching a video game.
I will have to admit, I had been waiting a long time to watch this movie. I wasn't able to go see it in theaters and so I had to wait for it to come out on BR, and they took a very long time to release it, so I had been anticipating for months on how superb the trailers looked and the first day of release  I went and purchased it. So maybe I was expecting too much?

I'm not exactly 'Rogers and Ebert'. but I know what I like and what I don't like.  Is this the best movie I ever saw?  No.  That would rate five stars and very few films qualify for that category.  Four stars came easy for this film.  It was excellent from the standpoint of story, action, and believability.  The apes were somewhat disturbingly 'human'.  There were heroes and despicable characters within the human and ape camps.  The story line shows the remnants of humanity trying to cope with shortages of everything ESPECIALLY energy.  If you've never considered life without the power grid, this will help you ponder the consequences.  Much of the story involves human attempts to restore some power.  Many of the negative attributes of humanity show up in this picture, even within the ape community.  This is a very enjoyable story and movie.  I highly recommend it for your viewing and entertainment.  The ending leaves plenty of room (and reasons) for another sequel.  Charlton Heston and Roddy McDowell would be pleased to see their legacy continue.  Anyone with a taste for mild Science Fiction would like this as would anyone with a sense of actual STORY-TELLING.

That ending is maybe the best movie ending of all time and there is no point of them trying to come up with their own "surprise" ending.  The Mark Wahlberg movie tried to do that and it was about the most stupid and non-sensical ending I have ever seen.

THE FILM: Not having seen any of the original 'Apes' films (even the Tim Burton remake), I really liked RISE OF THE PLANET OF THE APES because of its emotionally resonant story and awesome special effects. DAWN OF THE PLANET OF THE APES continues in the same vein, while covering different thematic territory. No new ground is broken, per se, but the manner in which it is presented and the talent involved lend it some freshness which would otherwise have been missing from what is already a really good film. DAWN takes place about 10 years after the events of RISE, when the Simian flu has killed off a large portion of the human population. The apes have migrated to the forests and started their own primitive civilization, while the humans hang on to what little they have left in the ruins of the city. With fuel about to run out, they seek to gain access to a power-generating dam, but that dam is located right in the middle of ape territory. Soon, mistrust on both sides leads to a conflict that has far-reaching consequences. One thing I noticed continually while watching this was how far special effects have come. It was only 15 years ago (or so) that we were still using people in ape suits to portray apes, but now since RISE, they are done in motion capture. They already looked really good and photorealistic in RISE, but here in DAWN they look even better. I think that Andy Serkis did some of his best work ever here, and also the actor who played Koba, Caesar's right hand "man" (and later, nemesis). The digital augmentation of the sets and locations was also seamless and created a world you could really believe in. Anyway, moving on to more important aspects. The human cast was all portrayed very well, the standout being Jason Clarke as Malcolm. His character is kind of a human counterpart to Caesar, in that he only wants what is best for his family, and that he is more pragmatic when it comes to certain situations. There's also Gary Oldman as Dreyfus, someone who leans more towards the confrontational side, like Koba. Even though I think his character wasn't given enough development, there was one scene which really sold you on his plight and gave the audience a potent emotional connection to him. Across the board, all of the performances were excellent. Thematically, the film deals with conflict and how we handle it, how it starts, how trust is broken. It's a very basic story, but one that should resonate with viewers of all ages. Also, with the ape culture, there's kind of Animal Farm thing going on where you have two leaders vying for the trust and respect of the people. This is replicated to a degree with the human cast, but the bulk of the movies' themes are handled when the apes are onscreen. This leads me to the only thing I can really pick on with the film: that is, while the themes are certainly important, they are handled in an overly broad and unsubtle way. The apes basically act as mouthpieces for the core ideas of the film, and at times you might be tempted to roll your eyes, but then you'll just move on because you're that absorbed in the world being created and emotionally involved with the characters. Overall, I think this represents a significant step up from the previous one, which was already very good to begin with. It's one of the best films to come out in Summer 2014, and I highly recommend that you see it.

THE EXTRAS: There's quite a few supplements to dig your teeth into. The first of these are three deleted/extended scenes with optional director's commentary. Only one of them really added anything to the story, but they were all interesting to watch. Then, there are a series of featurettes which cover every aspect of production, from development, the cast's experience and the groundbreaking special effects. What amazed me the most was just how much of the film was shot on location (about 80%), and the overall effort that went into creating a believable experience. There is also a photo gallery and a feature-length audio commentary by the director, Matt Reeves. Altogether, I thought that all of these extras were an interesting additional perspective on the making of the film, and its themes.

OVERALL: Although highly entertaining for all of the spectacular effects and the crazy action that takes place towards the end, it becomes more than a popcorn blockbuster by exploring some very human themes. To sweeten the deal, there are a number of enlightening extras that enhance the experience considerably. This Blu-ray package is a must-buy for fans of the series, and sci-fi fans in general.

If you have not viewed all the 'ape' movies you may not know why Caesar is more intelligent than the rest of the bunch, but really only slight; the movie does try to show how he was raised, but the back flashes could be confusing to novices.  The computer animation was good.  Only the horses gave it away... once in a while.  The combination was really very good.  The story line left much to be desired, the whole good versus evil thing.  If the apes ever do become intelligent and tired of the human treatment, beware.  They are stronger, faster, more agile, and can survive where we cannot.  The whole key is intelligent development.  Very good concept, well put together, and very entertaining, just wish there had been more story, but that's a chic thing.  Definitely rent-able.

Nice political subtext. The apes are the protagonists, the humans are irrelevant (the female humans, even more so, hence 1/2 a star docked). The first half of this film is mind-blowing. It's all Caesar and the apes - this is THEIR story. The second half falls into rote territory, with Koba following a familiar Hollywood arc for the antagonist (and that's where I took off another 1/2 star :) Koba starts out as a very interesting character. The part where he points to his scars and says "Human work" is compelling stuff. As a foil to Caesar, he's fanatastic. It's too bad the writers couldn't figure out a way to maintain his complexity and write a resolution that didn't compromise it. Sadly, they just toss all that complexity out and devolve Koba into your standard power-hungry bad guy. But these are small quibbles. The film is an intelligent, rampaging, "Hail Caesar!" critique of humanity. This is what good sci-fi is all about.

For me, I knew this sequel was a foregone conclusion after seeing the first movie.  My fear was that sequels sometimes fail to live up to the standard of the first movie.  That's not the case here.  This is not only a great sequel but, in many ways, a much better movie than the first.  In the three years since 'Rise of the Planet of the Apes', Wita Digital has made huge leaps in their digital technology and this movie has an even more realistic look than the first.  It also explores more of the relationships between the apes species and the human species.  And, of course, it leaves the possibility of another movie to keep this new franchise alive.  If you are a fan of all the Planet of the Apes going back to the original in 1968, I highly recommend 'Dawn of the Planet of the Apes'.  Just make sure you've seen 'Rise of the Planet of the Apes' first!

If you can utterly forget that the Planet of the Apes series had an actual beginning, this movie might be doable.  In the end, while the CGI really is good, without a believable STORY it all just falls flat.

Are we forgetting that the plot is moving towards a known end?  We've got to get these apes from tree-swingers to fluent English speakers sipping cognac while listening to classical music and harvesting humans like they were North Pacific salmon.

This movie moved us about an INCH towards that end.  It was utterly predictable, the whole way through, and delivered no real stand out performance that the audience could really connect with.

In the end, it's a nearly two-hour movie telling a five minute story.

The first Planet of the Apes movie with Charlton Heston was very well done for its time.  Each succeeding sequel was worse than the one before until they became B movies at best.  The reverse is true of the new ones, they just get better and better.

In this one the apes are living in the forest and think the humans are all gone because it has been so long since they saw one.  Then a group of humans, enroute to a dam to try to restore it to working order for the electricity, meet up with a couple of apes and things don't go well at all.  Caesar sends a couple of apes to the nearest town to scout out the situation.  Between the humans that want to kill the apes and the apes that want to kill the humans all out war erupts between the two.  The outcome of that is in doubt until the very end.

Unnecessary antagonists.
Unnecessary plot lines.
Infinite ammo guns!

So the flaws.
The surviving humans need power to survive in the remains of San Fran and they send a group out to find and repair a hydro electric plant and they bump into the apes.  The 1st problem; the bald plot antagonist guy freaks out and shoots and wounds an ape causing a huge problem ... but the apes let them go ... but the humans need to be there to fix the dam .... so they send this gun crazy guy BACK OUT after he clearly demonstrated that he was unstable.  HE DID NOT NEED TO BE IN THE MOVIE ... you had a good story already made ... the need to expand ... you know, how America was founded in the 1st place by Europeans ... I know that was a two fer with char and plot lines ...

Back in San Fran, Gary Oldman tells everyone WE HAVE GUNS ... which were guarded by two rednecks and noone else.  Seriously they let these two ppl test the weapons under the bridge by themselves and eventually the apes come and take these guns ... that were in absolutely  0 secured areas ... they were just sitting there under the bridge out in the open (Which weather would of destroyed them & the ammo)

Soooo, the apes get the guns and low-and-behold the guns never run out of ammo... .ever .... all the apes do is run around firing cause EVOLUTION!!!!.

Humans at this point deserve to lose ... you let infinite ammo guns lay out in the open and you send a small group of people out with crappy guns into the woods to explore, and when the apes do attack ... everyone just stands in the way ... only like 10ppl use their guns to try and fight off the apes....

Things I do like...

The plot with the Apes was pretty damn good... FAR better than any story the humans had going for them.
The apes for the most part (save the stupid action heavy scenes) CGI looks amazing.

Should you own it?  Sure it is a nice addition to the series, just wait for it to be on sale ... full price is a bit much for what this offers.

Wow, absolutely fantastic as a family movie. This is perfect to teach children about right and wrong. This film also teaches that because someone looks like you doesn't make them good for you. Now for those who don't have anyone to teach, you can just sit back and enjoy a really good movie. Action, Suspense with a great storyline should be sufficient to hold your attention. This is one of those films that require your complete attention if you want to get everything that this film has to offer. This film also stands on its own, so even if you did not see the first Planet of the Apes you can still enjoy this one. This is definitely a film that you will watch more than once.

Entertaining. A movie that doesn't feel like it was churned out of the holly wood movie mill *cough* Hercules *cough*. It is another movie however where you need to put your analytical side away. It doesn't make sense when you try and make sense of it. Initially the experiment was to just make people smarter where chimps were the test subjects, not rearrange their genetic structure so they'll want to stand all the time and eventually develop vocal chords. It's a play on evolution more or less.

wonderfully

Made me feel like I was a kid again. I always liked movies that have cities and other structures in some form of neglect from being abandoned by people. I liked the Muir Woods sign and the HWY 101 sign. The gas station was okay too until they got the power back on. It's hard to believe that it was up and running with all the lights, spinning ball sign, and music playing when the power went out. The power station itself looked like it had been abandoned for decades, and would have needed a lot more work to start producing electricity again. The power lines are all intact after years of no service? As for the story, well I guess there could be an ape that develops human intellect from taking some new concoction, but shouldn't it have been tested on rodents first? But then smart rats wouldn't be able to hold a machine gun, at least not in their own. Maybe a team of rats could have operated each weapon, but that would be more comical than scary. It's a good movie for a day off if you have nothing else to do, and don't put too much thought into it.

Originally, this had been slated to be a trilogy.  This third installment in the rebooted Apes franchise exhibits a remarkable story that stays relatively true to the original 70's cult classics while infusing a fresh Ape-centered storyline into the fore.  Over the course of the three films, the story's focus has shifted away from humanity to the apes.

Unsurprisingly, with today's advancing CG technology... the film comes off marvelously - beautifully.  There are scenes where it looks a bit campy... but these are done more to present story and are not lacking in cinematic beauty, just superfluous in story-building.

In a nutshell, the story picks up a decade after the events in the last film.  Caesar and his liberated primates have retreated to Muir woods while the whole of humanity descends into a post-apocalyptic contagion nightmare.  As any biological species would be faced with... the central challenge between the two groups is a simple one -- how do we survive?

The tension and emotional depth of and between the characters is palpable.  The director and writers do an excellent job of presenting a moral and ethical dilemma faced not by the humans, but by the apes.  I can imagine the story separating the audience into different factions as it does in the film.  Will you side with Caesar?  Or Koba?  And when you choose your camp, where will it take you?

This film presents an interesting question in its conclusion... Where will the story go from here?

I don't know exactly what I was expecting- two hours of intense fighting and a few profound messages, apparently- but I was disappointed.  Maybe the media hype was to blame.  The things that are indisputable are that 1) the CGI is so convincing that you, in your state of suspended disbelief, of course, never doubt the reality of what is before your eyes 2) the fighting and war scenes, when they do happen, are rightly spectacular, and 3) the acting of the male cast is excellent (Keri Russell's character was so quiet and so barely involved that a wet dishcloth could have carried the role).  One of the things that bothered me while watching was the pushing of the theme of family to the boundaries of ok, we get it, Ceasar's relationship with his son is running parallel to the human lead's relationship with his son.  In fact, it was the emotional cliches between honest action that bogged down the movie for me. The meant-to-be-heartstring-tugging moments were right out of the Hollywood trope trunk.  I had hoped for more.

This was my favorite movie of 2014.  The cinematography is great.  There is very little spoken dialogue, but Andy Serkis and the other motion capture actors added incredible emotion to the apes.
So much so that all characters feelings were very well conveyed.
The new Planet of the Apes is the only reboot I can think of better than the original movies.
The human characters were by far the weakest part of the film.  But this isn't Planet of the Humans.
The film squarely focuses on Ceasar, his family, and his immense wisdom to see the whole picture insteas of only the here and now.  Our current imperial president could learn a thing or two from Ceasar.  Ceasar is the smartest of all the Apes.  Ceasar does not want to be a king.  The ape who got the 2nd highest amount of exposure to the chemical is Koba.  Koba lived as a test subject in a lab.  Ceasar was raised by humans and has seen their good side.  This gives Ceasar a positive, peaceful, and hopeful worldview and Koba has the opposite.  Koba ended Rise of the planet of the Apes by pushing the CEOs helicopter off The Golden Gate Bridge.  This was seen as his revenge for the years of torture he received in the lab.  Koba thinks all humans are bad.  You could call him a racist to an extent.
Ceasar believes Apes and people can be good or bad.  Koba believes people are inherinetly bad.  Ceasar sees the good in people.  Its really a much more profound movie than it seems on the outside.
I'm very excited for the next installment of Ceasar, the peace loving Gandhiesque monkey.

The original APES franchise is something that never really interested me. I enjoyed the premise of the film, but just felt that it was too overblown and it didn't help that Charlton Heston gives one of his hammiest performances, so I didn't really have much interest in seeing any of the sequels. However, reading the incredibly strong reviews for RISE OF THE PLANET OF THE APES piqued my interest, and it's always fantastic to see Andy Serkis doing his motion capture performances, and I loved that film. It had strong performances, a strong heart and a strong message. When I heard that Matt Reeves had been selected to direct this sequel to the prequel, I was on board almost immediately, and seeing such a strong cast with Jason Clarke, Keri Russell, Gary Oldman and Serkis returning as Caesar, seeing DAWN OF THE PLANET OF THE APES was a no-brainer. And while I didn't love it as much as the previous installment, there's still a lot to admire and appreciate.

The film opens with the revelation that it has been 10 years since the previous film, and due to the experimental drug that Caesar and the apes were exposed to that gave them human intelligence but revealed was deadly to humans, most of the world's human population has died off in what was called "The Simian Flu", and the few that remain in this post-pandemic society are genetically immune. In that time, Caesar and his fellow test subjects have built a home for themselves in the Muir Woods outside San Francisco. They live off the land and don't interfere with the remaining humans as long as they are not interfered with themselves. The human remnants in San Francisco, led by the strength of Dreyfus (Oldman) and the brains of Malcolm (Clarke), are running out of time, though. They need electricity, and the only source capable is the dam near Muir Woods. When they venture out into it, all of the apes are distrusting initially, but once Malcolm, his doctor girlfriend Ellie (Russell) and his artist son Alexander (Kodi Smit-McPhee) are able to establish trust, Caesar welcomes them to complete their work and leave them in peace. However, Caesar's friend/rival Koba hates humans because of the terrible experimentation done on him when he was in their labs and sets into motion events that will force apes and humans clash in a struggle that could prove to be cataclysmic for both.

There are a few things that really set DAWN apart from RISE. First is the world building. Reeves, the director of CLOVERFIELD and the English language remake of the brilliant Swedish vampire film LET THE RIGHT ONE IN (simply called LET ME IN), and writers Mark Bomback, Rick Jaffa and Amanda Silver have really created a lived-in world for the apes and the humans to inhabit and explore, which is fantastic. Second is the CG and motion-capture work, which is eye-poppingly amazing. There's never a moment's doubt that what you're seeing is real. Third is that, despite the presence of powerful performers like Oldman, Clarke and Russell, this is very much a film about the apes and not the humans, and that's not a complaint. However, it doesn't leave give any of the human characters much to do. This is also the first film I've ever seen where the lead performer is the mo-cap performer ahead of the actual on-screen actors, which is also not a complaint, since Serkis does some incredible and wonderful work here as Caesar, not just as a mo-cap performer but as an actor. He brings gravitas and understanding to Caesar; something that is largely absent in most mo-cap performances.

The moral of the tale isn't lost on me either (although it was when I was watching the film), which seems to be that giving an animal human intelligence will also give way to animals behaving with both the best and the worst that humanity has to offer. I was uncomfortable initially with the film's story primarily being about how the apes can be just as bad as we can, particularly since the first film was much more about how the noble nature of the animals exceeding humanity's understanding of them. But after thinking about it, it made a lot more sense. In effect, Caesar and Koba are the MLK/Malcolm X or Professor X/Magneto of the APES universe, and by pitting one against the other, the film takes on a more significant meaning.

Aside from some plot contrivances and some cliched characters, DAWN OF THE PLANET OF THE APES is a very strong, well-made and well-executed film that will leave most audiences clamoring for the next installment.

I really like where this franchise is going, story and performances from Ape actors are amazing! I like that the film focuses on the apes more than the humans, as it is supposed to (not like latest Godzilla for example, where the infamous monster only appears for 20 minutes in a 2 hour movie named after him). And the apes are complex, very political, very family oriented, very proud. Jason Clarke does a good job as the generic human good guy (Honestly it could've been any actor. I think they should have casted Mark Wahlberg to make up for the bad Planet of the Apes reboot from 2001. Not his fault, it was Tim Burton's weird take on the franchise).
  The other thing I thought of when I saw this film was 12 Monkeys. One reviewer made a reference to Contagion, but I thought of the 12 Monkeys movie where the monkey symbols were spray painted on the walls of the city when the deadly virus killed everyone in that film (in the scene when the apes entered the city, the walls were spray painted with the words "Simien Flu" and a monkey/ape painted next to it).
  Overall, an excellent film, better than 'Rise' in my opinion (which never happens, sequels are usually not better than the first film). I really like the character development, especially Ceasar (played by Andy Serkis, who deserves an Oscar nomination) as the Ape leader/savior. I highly recommend this film!

If you enjoy movies with underlying rhetoric and symbolism, this movie is packed with it. Almost every line and interaction between characters is symbolic for something important and/or controversial/moral.

It is a long movie. There is a plot (Even if you can't seem to point it out.)

If you can't handle long movies and can't find/enjoy rhetorical meaning, then don't watch it (Like Lord of The Rings, Harry Potter, etc).

This movie has tons of closure. Most of your questions are answered to satisfaction (except for the cliche, "if he didn't do that, none of this would have had to happen" scenario, comes up alot).

The movie is as follows,

Spoiler.....

Caesar and his right hand Ape - A leader of an Ape civilization - A crew of humans - and a Bigot (with the crew of humans) walk into a bar. The bigot shoots an Ape's child, and from there the movie starts.

I found this sequel just had nothing original plot wise in it at all that we haven't seen in thousands of other films (most without monkeys).  Although the CGI was technically good, to me the apes facial expressions were too human like to be believable as primates.  They came across as very cartoon like in their behaviour and conversations with each other, it would have been more realistic if they had just used the sign language and kept is as a basic understanding of what each animal wanted for the other.

Plot was weak though (spoilers). There's the power struggle, the leadership challenge, the betrayal, the left for dead but he's not really, the hanging by your fingers about to plunge to your death and other character has to make a moral decision.  The original modern version spin on the old Planet of the Apes film franchise was good, because it was different and entertaining, and made you care about both the human and ape characters.  This one was boring, predictable and ultimately a waste of time.

Excellent movie. I have been a fan of the franchise for over 30 years. I liked the reboot, but this is by far the best of the last three. I think the action would work well for anybody whether or not they know the franchise. The storyline might not be as good if you are unfamiliar, but in my opinion, this was made for fans of the franchise, as well as those that have not seen the previous installments.

Excellent, epic film that manages to actually do a great job of using technology to actually push film art forward, instead of sideways or backwards.  You could throw everything else out, and it is still worth seeing for the (mostly) amazing ability the advanced CGI and blending/production work.  The cinematography and writing are all very good as well, extremely well-produced and written on the whole for a big theater film.

There are some overly drawn out scenes that would've better without the "feel good" sappiness milked for too long, and the pace is too fast on the other end of things, possibly as a result of forced editing.  But the incredible tension throughout the story the film does a great job of conveying, the completely awesome action sequences, and the unpredictable nature of the events at times, make it completely worthwhile.

It really takes you back to the classic epic sci-fi and action movies of the 70's and 80's, where you felt yourself pulled emotionally towards the main characters, rooting for one group or another, and sitting-up during the tense sequences. You care about Caesar, his family/friends, and the depictions of the apes in their environments and communicating with each other etc..., are completely amazing to watch, as it's something you'd never experienced before in film history, in this way or to this degree.

Final note: The "CGI" used, is still not perfect of course, it's just really, really well done, and despite the bad name CGI is getting over the years, Dawn proves there's an amazing future for virtual reality in film when it is done right, and also incredibly powerful.

This 2nd part is really good, combines spectacular and message, something difficult to see in a summer blockbuster.

I highly recommend it.

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes takes place ten years after humans have been nearly wiped out. The apes have built a thriving community in the deep forest. The chimpanzee Caesar (Andy Serkis) has a family: wife Cornelia (Judy Greer), teen son Blue Eyes (Nick Thurston), and a baby on the way. Former adversary Koba (Toby Kebbell) has become an ally, while aging orangutan Maurice (Karin Konnoval) mentors the young and serves as adviser to the adults.

In this post-pandemic world, there are pockets of surviving humans. A small group, consisting of architect Malcolm (Jason Clarke), former Centers for Disease Control nurse Ellie (Keri Russell), and Malcolms teenage son, Alexander (Kodi Smit-McPhee), hope to reactivate a deserted power plant on the apes turf to provide electricity. Caesar gives permission, provided all guns are surrendered.

The actors portraying the apes far outshine those portraying humans. Computer-generated images are seamlessly blended with superior make-up that enables the actors to convey emotion. The apes communicate in a form of simple sign language, translated in subtitles.

Mr. Serkis (Gollum in The Lord of the Rings films) has probably the most expressive eyes in movies today. His presence is so commanding that we are glued to him whenever hes on screen. His close-ups convey exactly what Casesar is thinking, particularly when confronted with unanticipated problems. We believe Caesar as a leader because of Mr. Serkis compelling work.

Also amazing is Mr. Kebbells Koba, a creature who was tortured by humans in laboratory experiments, bears their scars, and is understandably distrustful of humans. Mr. Kebbell gives Koba an intimidating personality that makes many of his fellow simians cower in fear.

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is available in three editions: 3D Blu-ray/Blu-ray; standard Blu-ray; and a double-feature DVD combining Dawn of the Planet of the Apes with its predecessor, Planet of the Apes. The Blu-ray editions contain a digital copy.

Amazing, how the reboot of the Planet of the Apes franchise is producing such terrific films - this one being no exception.  A fan of the original series, I was wholly impressed with its predecessor, but Dawn easily lives up to it, with the level of special effects achievable in film today worthy of these stories ... yet not overshadowing them, instead giving you a backdrop of mostly-ape characters that you grow to love and care about even more than their human counterparts.  Here, ten years after a pandemic (the "simian flu") has killed off most of the world, in San Francisco a remaining faction of humans must access a dam in order to keep their power going - and find it rests in the middle of the forest land apes have called home since Caesar led the revolution years ago.  Will peace, or war, will win in the end?  With both sides having both friends and enemies within their own camp, it comes down to Caesar and the human's leader Malcolm (Jason Clarke) to try and keep things civil even as war is plotted from within.  Brilliant film.

"The Dawn of the Planet of the Apes" is a retrospective about the human race, chimps, and interspecies participation.

Caesar the Ape, mimed so skillfully by Andy Serkis, is a grown up ape with a lot of responsibilities, the first being his gargantuan responsibility towards Apedom as a whole--he is a leader now, and his past vanished with the Simian Flu, an Ape borne illness that also wiped out most of mankind.  Of course, the blame is shared, because as Keri Russell says to that guy from Oz: "The virus was created by scientists working in a lab.  You can't blame the apes."  He does, of course, and I was personally jubilant when Koba took him out.

This does not have the comparatively light touch of "Rise".  Caesar is a husband and father of a baby ape and a grown up ape, Blue Eyes.  There are parallels on every side of the struggle, but the humans are not the first to *break out* the firepower.  An apocalyptic world, one sees the chimps behave in much the same way as humanity--till Caesar, the Ape equivalent of a Che Guevara or ferocious Gandhi, becomes leader again.  Recommended heavily.

"Dawn of the Planet of the Apes" (2014) takes place ten years after the previous film, 2011's "Rise of the Planet of the Apes." The virus unleashed at the end of that film has wiped out most of the human race, but a large group of survivors live in a walled section of San Francisco while the chimp Caesar and his band of apes live in the forests north of the city. The humans need to take control of the dam near the ape's village to secure power for their city, which leads to both friendly and hostile relations. Jason Clarke, Gary Oldman and Keri Russell lead the human cast.

This film's on par with the previous one, so if you liked that one you'll like this one too. The CGI is both good and yet cartoony. Strangely, the CGI in "Jurassic Park" was better, and that was 21 years ago! But, hey, they're better that the FX on Syfy and you get used to 'em after the first act.

The forest cinematography is awesome, but the story is only mildly compelling. The characters are okay, but bland and the plot fairly predictable. For instance, when Keri' Russell's character goes to the ape village you know exactly what she's going to do; and when Caesar spares a fellow ape you know exactly what that ape's going to do. Overall, I was expecting better, but it's a decent addition to the apes saga and ranks about the 4th or 5th best in the entire series.

The film runs 130 minutes and was shot at Golden Ears Provincial Park, Campbell River & Vancouver, British Columbia with beauty shots of San Francisco.

GRADE: B-  (or a weak 4/5 Stars)

Perhaps this gritty realism trend has gone too far in movies.  In the original POTA, thousands of years had passed so it made sense that the apes had evolved to be more humanoid.  Their advanced state also helped the theme/juxtaposition of devolved humans vs advanced apes and the underlying political themes/commentary.  In the 2014 version, apes have taken a genetic short cut to intelligence, so you literally have monkeys talking/signing.  Looks a bit odd.  Story is well executed, but generic.

How do you rate this movie? A 2? A 3? Perhaps a 4? A 5? I like how one person summarized it, "Just watch it. You will like it."  Likely true.  I think the younger you are, the more likely you will rate this movie more highly because of the overused plot twists and characters will not seem so obvious.

I think it isn't hard to see that this is a blockbuster movie and will be liked by many.  So, I am not going to rehearse the many great things as others have already said.  I ended up with 4 stars, so I must have liked it (and I did). But what will drive you nuts about this movie?  What will be the part that will make you wonder if this is really a great movie or not??  See below.  :)

It isn't a minute into the film when the human villian [played by the normally excellent Kirk Acevedo)shoots one of the apes in cold blood.  Then the major plot line is etched, "Will the humans and the apes be friends, or will there be a fight?"  Is that one element enough to keep you watching?  Yeah, It works... just not well.  Not too long after Kobo (the bad ape) is shown as the villian for the apes.  And now the two bad ones will take turns destroying the fragile peace.  ugh.  It gets old.

After Kirk Acevedo shoots the boy ape, our hero "Malcomb" decides he is going to take him up to Ape country to help fix the generator.  WHAT!?  You want to scream, if you hadn't already guessed this moron would be the reason everything goes south.  You know it before the next hour and a half shows us... and thus, the movie just doesn't hold our attention as much as it could have.  And with the bad ape wondering around, we know there will be friction on both sides.  And if you know the basic story line, you KNOW that this is (after all) the PLANET OF THE APES, so that at some point, humans are going to go down.  Will it be in this movie? In the next?  How will it come about?  That we do not know and I will not ruin what little tension exists with such a disclosure.

Love that the apes can talk.  Love the basic set-up for the show.  A flu-strain... think ebola on steroids... called the simian flu has wiped out 499 out of every 500 humans on the planet.  We follow some humans near the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco...of course, the same area of Ceasar and the Apes that we see in Rise of the Planet of the Apes.  This only makes sense.

But then comes serious plot twist two: The humans are now without power (it's been 10 winters since "Rise")  and must fix the Hydroelectric plant to get more.

Wait! You may think.  "Power?  Isn't this the very BANE of HUMAN existence???!!!  Of course.  And so, the next plot twist is not without a certain dread that the humans will NOT be successful... as the APES have the moral high ground of needing no electricity and no power (except for the guns which they strangely like).  See, if you love the idea of humans living without power and not damaging the earth's ecosystem with power hungry devices, then you will likely LIKE this plot development... you know that it is doomed for failure.  If you, on the other hand, prefer human survival, you will likely see this as a needless plot line....because you too know it is doomed for failure.

So, while we give the movie kudos for a believable way to kill off so many people (despite the fact that in the original it is a nuclear war to blame), we simply think that the film could have been developed so much better than, "Will the humans and apes fight and what will happen because of it."  4minutes into the show we know the whole thing.

Our lead actor is acceptable, but very forgettable. Don't even recall his name any more.  I would not knowingly go to see a movie because he was in it.  That seems a strange choice for such a high budget film. At least, if you are going with an unknown actor for a lead in a block buster, give us someone memorable and highly likable.

Excellent special effects (aside from the bad special effects of the chimps on horses where they grow two feet to be able to straddle the horses)>  Odd.

I do believe this movie will be among the more forgettable ones, aside from action sequences.  Still 4 stars for a great ending and for extending the great franchise... and giving us so many places to go with the next Planet of the Apes movie.  I think the next one could be the best new Ape movie.

Violence?  Yes. Of course, it is a war scene at end.  Plenty of blood, so be aware.  Cussing?  Yes, including F-word.  No drugs or overt sexual escapades that I recall.  Hatred?  Plenty, on both sides.

Basic theme of movie is good.  There are good people, there are bad people.  There are good apes, there are bad apes.  "We are a lot alike."
Next movie likely will be Human army arriving to snuff out what remains of the Ape community in San Francisco area.  Apes will of course protect themselves.  Don't expect that Ceasar will be in charge when all is over, but who knows.  If the Apes must take over (to be the Planet of the Apes), then they will have to win some wars over humans.  Or, perhaps they will simply return to the franchise take... the men come in.... try to win... are not, so they drop nukes.... destroying themselves more than they destroy the Apes... then, years later, it is the Apes in control of the Planet. See, I think next movie or two will be very intersesting.  How do we get from peace loving Ceasar to the Planet of the Apes.  Looking forward to it.

Very enjoyable, despite the poor build and arcane bits. 4 stars.

Good flic. Top to bottom, moves fast...It's a long film, but doesn't seem so. Entertaining, no cursing, no blood bath killing.
Try it. Don't read the reviews. They're long boring, tell the story & usually wrong.
Great special effects  lame plot .... WAR...no wait....WAR...no wait...WAR etc etc etc

Not a stunning sequel, but it does do quite a lot well.  It feels like the old Planet of the Apes movies.  It's weird and and wonderful, a pleasure to gawk at.  Even the score is a throw-back to those classic films.  The inclusion of massive amounts of CGI does not hurt this movie one bit.  The acting is perfect.  The apes are all too human at times, terrifying at others, and unsettling the rest of the time.

This is a great post apocalyptic sci-fi movie, plain and simple.  Keeps you watching, keeps you guessing, and adds quite a lot of character conflict into the mix.  You really never know what is going to happen.

The only flaws are in characterization and the ending.  We know little about everybody, except Caesar.  Nothing interesting about anybody.  Just throw-away characters, really.  Except Caesar and some of his crew.  They have some character--pun intended.  But mostly because we know them from the first movie.  There is a lame father-son dynamic pushed down our throats on each side of this conflict, but it eases off just as it gets vomit-worthy.

The ending is pretty dumb.  It's just an obvious set up for another movie.  It feels like there are a few scenes missing when the credits roll.  Oh well.  Monkey see as monkey do.

If you loved the last film, BUY IT.  If not, rent it.  Worth seeing.

This movie is definitely a ride from beginning to end!

The character development of Caesar and Koba is magnificent.  Some parts are a tad bit hokey, but for the most part, the story truly draws you in to the mindset of the apes, how they got to the point they either loved or hated humans and how that transcends into the previous POTA movies.

Koba makes this movie more interesting than ANY of the characters in my opinion.  You have to see this ape go from already hater to reason to hate even more.

Caesar's role in the movie makes him almost too human in my opinion, but nonetheless, Andy kills again!  Seeing his family go through tribulation and come out of it, to some degree (thanks to Koba's mistake(s)) makes it all worthwhile in the end.

I can't wait until the third installment.  I'm curious to see how they develop Maurice and Caesar's son.

A decent, but not an outstanding sequel to Rise of the Planet of the Apes.  We enjoyed the movie, especially the intro linking it to the original movie ending.  The Ape make up and costumes were as remarkable as the first movie.  The forest scenes were very good and the human characters acting was somewhat believable.

I don't understand is why Director's decide to end movies that have the potential for being special with the main characters fighting for there lives in computer generated construction sites.  It nearly became like we were watching an animated movie which we were.

And unlike the well made, acted and visually pleasing original movie there was no lead in into the next movie.

I give it a four I think it should have a stronger women in the movie not just one main woman.
But for me this new version is different for someone that remember the original 5 movies
This movies is still worth the purchase and to watch.

Best of the Apes..about says it all. I am old enough to have watched them all since the beginning and must say this was well worth waiting for and watching. Gary Oldman is a damn good actor.. anyways... Amazing how the series continues. Will always have a place for the original but modern with CGI is just fantastic. Life just breathes in this version. Great acting and script. I wish I could be in the next one!! lol!!!

This is a very good movie that covers only part of a story. This movie is a bridge, a crucial part of the overall tale. It had bits and pieces of what was supposed to be in the second movie of the original Planet of the Apes. Great movie, wonderful special effects and very good performances. Worth every dime. Enjoy.

After watching the first movie and enjoying it so much, I couldn't wait for the sequel. Normally sequels do not hold up to the original, but in the case of Dawn of the Planet of the Apes, they really came through for the audience. I love the interaction and mistrust elements between the two separate species. They really moved the story along in a way that makes perfect sense for both. You get an overall feeling there is no good guys and bad guys. Great cast, entertaining effects that don't overshadow the story line, and an ending that will make you wish that the 3rd installment in the franchise was already out. I'm not sure how many they plan on making because the older movies from the 70's went on too long, but if they make a remarkable ending for the next movie, it would be a perfect trilogy. You can't make Planet of the Apes any better than this without losing what it's all about... Separation leads to conflict, working as one collective unit makes you stronger with a much better chance for ALL to survive.

AUDIO REVIEW- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h_E2IJ4eYIc&list=UUCqEeDAUf4Mg0GgEN658tkA&index=75
was a great movie. planet of ape fans its a must have movie.  cant wait until I own it.

Best movie of 2014 by far other than guardians of the galaxy, I thought it was impossible over the past few years to make a sequel that was better than the original but this movie beat that theory. This movie is to me an instant classic like Forrest Gump. It kept every one in the audience in their seats some even running to the bathroom very quickly because of this epic movie. It made you wanna watch it again and again if it replayed in theaters. I can't wait for 3

I loved the first one and I Love THIS one too!!! I can't wait to watch it a million more times because I was crying so much the first time in the theater. If you get invested in the characters you won't be able to help it!!
Excellent.  Another great Planet of The Apes movie.

I saw this movie based on metacritic reviews who I thought I could trust because they sounded like they knew what they were talking about, I was wrong and that's why I felt I needed to review this movie. In actuality, this movie is pretty bad. The sheer number of things wrong w/ this movie I could just keep listing off on and on.

Ok so, first, the tribal face paint, where did they learn that? Why is that necessary? Is this some cultural, religious, or some war paint kind of thing? Just a movie thing to make them look scarier I guess but doesn't make any sense. The battering ram, again, where did they learn that? Book reading or time travel to medieval ages? One of the biggest parts of this movie that doesn't make any sense is why none of the humans take the apes seriously. When the ape virus goes worldwide and kills millions and being on worldwide news, NOBODY in the future remembers this?!?! C'mon!! It also doesn't help that you'd think, well.. at least you'd Think that an ape talking after becoming increasingly intelligent (oh yea.. also TALKS) while helping cure alheimers disease would be beyond HUGE news, right? Nope! Apparently everyone in the future has forgotten their history. Either way that alzheimers was cured w/ an increasingly intelligent monkey that didn't make the news or, people in the future have forgotten their history, either way, doesn't any sense. Towards the ending they needed a forced climatic moment so what do they do? Instead of doing a simple explanation (no spoilers) of what Really happened the entire situation could've been avoided, but what happens? He doesn't say anything and leads to this unnecessary Hollywood Michael Bay explosion and then this dumb fight that could've been avoided. With everything that's wrong w/ this movie, it even manages to drag down the previous movies as well as they won't make as much sense as much, this is how bad this movie is.

So w/ everything wrong w/ this movie why 2 stars? The cgi is incredible, the apes, the city, everything looks amazing. Voice over work was really well done as well. That's all about all the positives of this movie.

Overall:
I would recommend this film to people if they need something to watch as it is a fun watch, but if you're looking for a good movie, don't waste your time.

Good special features alone do not a good movie make. I loved Rise of the Planet of the Apes. It did what Tim Burton could not (despite the help from studly Mark Wahlberg) - reinvigorate a decades-dormant franchise. Femmes of a certain age will recall with delight the sights of Charlton Heston and James Franciscus in the movies that started it all: the original Planet of the Apes and the far more disturbing Beneath the Planet of the Apes (oh, what has become of our human race, yikes!). Franciscus was a God among men (I say that as a Christian-minded gal, too) and it's so tragic he passed prematurely. But along comes the person who just might be his natural successor, Mr. James Franco - he of the arm-severing 127 Hours (brilliance!). Rise was, in a word, a marvelous entertainment.

Gary Oldman is a great actor but he can't be blamed for failing to "nail" his character here in Dawn - well, no one wrote one for him to play, in the first place! This is predictable, by the numbers storytelling from start to finish and does almost NOTHING to advance the new Apes timeline begun in Rise. Well, of course it establishes the new intelligence and self-awareness of the Caesar-led apes. But that was conveyed in the 2 minute trailer! We simply didn't need a full movie to make it apparent.

[Warning - Plot Spoilers]

As others have remarked, the movie opens with simulated news clips of a pandemic spreading across the globe. One clip briefly shows Obama, with a voice pretending to be his offerings words of reassurance. To those readers who never voted for him, that would elicit cynical sighs. But some of you may also remember when Reagan was president, and another sci-fi movie [I forget which] about aliens visiting Earth showed him 'saying' we should welcome them. Crikey, 26 years ago!

Aside from that, as I write this, the US now has detected another local Ebola victim. So the movie is quite unintentionally topical, though years later when perhaps you might be reading this, it will be thusly dated.

There are many awkward points about the movie, some of which other reviewers may already have pointed out. But one thing is stark, to anyone who has operated a ham radio. The movie shows the humans in San Francisco needing to hook up to electricity from a dam nearby. When they do this, the lights on the skyscrapers turn on. But beforehand, we are told that they only have a few weeks of diesel fuel left and things are getting critical. Well, after the hookup, they now use a radio transmitter to contact other survivors elsewhere. Here's the skinny. You don't need a lot of electricity to do this. Then by bouncing your signal across the ionosphere, you can reach across the globe. A portable diesel generator, or indeed any source of minimal electricity will suffice. Marconi and others effectively did this over a century ago.

Ham operators already do this, all the time. Point is, the SF chaps would already have contacted others at the start of the movie.

Another tricky point will be clear to any or many of you familiar with firearms. The apes are using guns designed for human hands. Unless Larmarck was right, they could not have evolved so quickly [10 years!] to facilely have comparable fingers. And none of them are shown practising with the guns they captured. Cmon! Humans using guns for the first time would be terrible shots.

Yet another is the bowlderising that was going on. We never see the genitalia of the apes. Unlike the apes in the 60s and 70s movies, all these apes are naked. Yes, males have smaller genitals relative to their size than humans. But even so, notice if you watch the movie how all that is brushed over, literally. Look carefully and you see nothing. Reminds me of that movie a few years ago which had real pigs in it. Some were depicted as males. But all the actual pigs were female, because the director did not want the male genitalia visible in the shots.

Having said all this, the movie is still enjoyable. To some extent, the plot and screenwriters did the best they could to smooth over the implausibilities. And let's wait for the next episode !!

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is the follow-up to 2011s Rise of the Planet of the Apes and truly Dawn of the Planet of the Apesputs the mesmerizingly talented Andy Serkis in the spotlight that he truly deserves. Serkis reprises his motion-capture role as Caesar, leader of the now highly evolved population of apes. Ten years have passed since the battle of San Francisco. The H5N1 virus, nicknamed the Simian Flu, has killed off most of humanity except for a miniscule group of people immune to the virus. The apes have migrated to the forests and have evolved to such a degree that they have built a civilization that has allowed them to develop an entire culture. Oddly the fantastic score by Michael Giacchino during an early scene where the apes demonstrate a highly advanced hunting technique is reminiscent of the score from 2001 A Space Odyssey that accompanies that films apes making an important evolutionary step.

It is this kind of subtext that makes the film so impressive. As the surviving humans realize they are running out of fuel, they conclude that their only hope is repairing a power-generating dam that is smack in the middle of the apes new civilization. Fear and paranoia mount on both sides as a stage is set worthy of Shakespeare, Serkiss character being named Caesar clearly being intentional. Caesars memory of compassionate humans causes him to hesitantly permit a group of humans lead by Ellie (Keri Russel) and Malcolm (Jason Clarke) to repair the dam. Ellie and Malcolm are two Chimp-athetic humans, if I may use a phrase coined by Entertainment Weeklys film critic Chris Nashawaty, but many of the other humans are not including the desperate human leader Dreyfus (Gary Oldman) who will not allow his people to sink back to the uncivilized life they had before setting up their current compound in San Francisco.

Of course, misplaced trust and a few bad apples on both sides threaten the safety and livelihood of both man and ape resulting in the threat of another all-out war. Caesar and Malcolm are tasked with the mission of trying to maintain peace.

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is an incredibly good looking movie and one with momentary glances of brilliance. Most of the films success can be attributed to the expressive Andy Serkis, however. Never in all of his underrated performances has he given a performance so emotional, raw, and empathetic. Caesar is an ape of few words, regardless of his ability to speak, and his face (and consequently Serkiss) communicates complex emotions unlike anything we have seen him convey before. If Tilda Swintons performance in Snowpiercer starts the Summer Oscar conversation, Serkiss totally immersive performance as Caesar certainly adds to it.

If you're looking for something to wash that bad taste Transformers: Age of Extinction left in your mouth, then a Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is just the thing. A-

A pretty good story, that lacked the emotional impact and thoughtfulness of the first. And dark. More lighting would have not made sleep so tempting. Perhaps it was to hide the necessary CGI, if the lights were on.
Nothing special. Not a very good movie but still entertaining. It was too predictable.
Amazing
Amazing movie! Very meaningful

A surprising good movie, it is a great sequel that gets started fast and engages the viewer while making us empathize with non-human characters. It's satisfying, well acted and the visuals are fantastic. Only 4 stars from me because of the cliche "have to fight the bad guy somewhere cool" climax and, let's face it, that title is just clunky. Very much worth your time and money.

From Sorry to characters to action... This is a fantastic sequel to Rise. It's Well paced and doesn't deviate from the motion of it's predecessor. If you're looking for hard hitting action, It's there too. Just don't expect to be blown away. This is definitely a story based movie more than anything else. But you definitely get your moneys worth.
Recommended purchase.

I love the original Planet of the Apes, as most people do, hated the Tim Burton remake and thought that Rise of the Planet of the Apes was a decent soft reboot of this series. Well, Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is an absolutely sublime near masterpiece. I wasn't expecting much from this and was completely blown away. THIS movie is in the great tradition of classical science-fiction where a concept or idea is used to explore the human condition while also intelligent and thoughtful in ways that would have made Rod Serling proud.

I mention Serling because The Twilight Zone is my most beloved TV show of all time and his approach is exactly how Sci-fi should be while Rod also had a hand in scripting the original 1968 film. Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is such a rich and rewarding movie. The Direction, scripting, acting, FX etc... everything is AAA+ and restors my faith that high quality Sci-fi movies CAN be made in Hollywood. It's frankly amazing that 20th Century Fox was able to put out not only Dawn but X-Men Days of Future Past as well!?! This is the studio that was ridiculed for being unable to make anything other than brainless garbage. Fox used to make soo many fantastic movies but Tom Rothman ran the studio into the ground for almost 20 years. I don't think it's a coincidence that he left Fox in 2012 and we now get two excellent genre films from the studio that used to make soo many great ones before that tool took over.

Anywho, 10 years after a viral outbreak, a simian civilization is flourishing having had no contact with the remnants of humanity after most of it has died out. An encounter with a band of humans, who seek to restart a hydro electric damn in Ape territory, sparks new conflict.

This movie is perfect on almost every level. Director Matt Reeves' Direction is classical in style while he avoids using any horrible shakey cam for the action sequences. The cinematography is sumptuous with stong earthly colors and nary a lens filter to be seen. The editing is tight but also knows when to let the performances breath. The Visual Effects are perfect. Each Ape has character and the performance capture gets great results. The acting is wonderful and a score that supports the visuals tops it of to perfection.

I just want to make special mention of the script. EVERY SINGLE CHARACTER has very clear motivations and you can understand were they are coming from. There are no real villains here, just people with different agendas that have been informed by their experiences. That's great writing. I really can't wait to see what the next chapter is in this series but my hope is that they can craft a better film which will be a tall order as Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is one of the best sequels ever made and virtually perfect in ever way.
I LOVE IT...Brilliant!!!
I want to buy is now...can't wait til it comes out on dvd. It was everything you need in a movie...action, love, thriller, and heroism.  My son loved it and so did my daughter...get the movie!!

Oh. My. God. What an amazing movie that was. Back in the day, when Rise of the Planet of the Apes was released, I thought "meh, I won't like it, it's a popcorn film, blah, blah, blah." However, a friend invited me to the cinema to watch it, and I loved it. You see, I'm not familiar with the original series, but as a stand-alone film, Rise was awesome. The problem was, there weren't enough ape scenes. But now, Dawn has a lot more apes, a lot more action, which means, you'll have a much better time. The movie is so meticulously detailed, it's jaw-dropping. You won't think the apes are actually people acting and wearing a strange black costume (until you see a behind the scenes), because the special effects are so amazing. I'll be sure to pick this movie up when it comes out. If you are a fan of the original series or just like action movies, this is an awesome movie for you.

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes
 Unlike the recent hyper-successful crash and bang Transformers 4 Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is a character driven movie.  Does that sound strange to say about a film with a $170 million budget that involves talking simians?  Ye, but it nevertheless rings true.  We love thePlanet of the Apes franchise because of the whole human/ape role reversal thing which we think is soooo cool.  We got that right, it is cool.  This one is billed as a Sci-Fi/Action flick.  It should be labeled as a grand tragedy, filmed on a wide canvas like War and Peace but with chimps instead of the French as antagonists.  Or something.
 The main human characters are Dreyfus, the leader of the human survivors living precariously in San Francisco, played with unusual enthusiasm by the usually lower octane Gary Oldman.  Keri Russell plays Ellie, the girl, an undeveloped character who is little more than window dressing.  The roles available for women in big action flicks are nearly always undeveloped, to our lasting shame.  Jason Clarke plays Malcolm, her fellah and acts as the main conduit for the Ape-Human interchange that does not involve mutual murder.  Still only in her mid thirties, we remember Russell from her TV show Felicity, the current The Americans and other TV and film work. Australian born Jason Clarke has diverse skills as shown by his roles in the TV cult hit Farscape, White House Down, The Rabbit-Proof Fence and Wall Street: The Money Never Sleeps.  He is put on screen with Chimpanzees, which must be a tough assignment.
 Andy Serkis plays the Ape leader Caesar.  His henchman (hench-ape?) Koba is played by Toby Kebbel.  We cant tell who the actors are because they look and act like Apes.  Well, Apes who can talk.
 The take away from The Rise of the Planet of the Apes was the epic battle on the Golden Gate Bridge between the smart simians and people.  The take away here has to be the aching sense of impending doom.  The best of the humans-Malcolm- and the best of the Apes-Caesar-do everything they can do to find a modus operandi.  But we know how volatile monkeys can be.  We know how suspicious humans can be.  The good people in each community see the slowly evolving catastrophe, as does the audience.  The whole little world of Apes and Humans slides slowly to the edge of destruction.  They struggle like insects on fly paper against what seems the inevitable final clash which will ruin both communities and perhaps exterminate one or the other.  Healing a sick Chimp, even the boss Chimps wife, a noble act in and of itself, cannot stop the slide.
 We want to shout Stop the madness at the screen.
 Dawn of the Planet of the Apes comes out on the top of the fairly high pile of films in this series going all the way back to Charlton Heston.  The writers and the director must take the bows for this success.  A trio of writers had their fingers and their ideas on the script.  Action pro Mark Bomback has a string of middling hits behind him.  He wrote Live Free or Die Hard in 2007, The Wolverine last year, the barely watchable Total Recall of 2012 and the underrated Unstoppable of 2010 with Chris Pine and Denzel Washington.  Bomback can do action.  He has written Fifty Shades of Grey which goes into release next year and has signed to write the next Apes movie.
 The other two writers are old collaborators.  Amanda Silver and Rick Jaffa also co-wrote Rise of the Planet of the Apes in 2011.  They mutually penned The Relic and Eye for an Eye.  Neither film made the Oscar nominations but both attracted people who like to go to the flickers and be startled out of their seats.  This seems an odd group to produce a film that for all the chest thumping and firefights remains a touching tragedy of interspecies misunderstanding, mistrust and misdeeds.  It seems odd but it works, it works very well.
 Director Matt Reeves has as his most notable directorial success the megahit, Cloverfield.  That movie made buckets of cash by scaring the bejeebers out of the audience.  I mean new Cadillacs for the pool boy buckets of cash.  Reeves has never had the responsibility of such a big budget film before.  He found a way to make something unique and much better than we had a right to expect.  He will be back to direct the next Planet of the Apes film in 2016.  Reeves directed Keri Russell in the Felicity series back in 1998.
 I give a strong four saw-blades to Dawn of the Planet of the Apes.  It is rated a fairly mild PG-13 for violence.  People do not take their clothes off in this one.  It has already made $103 million in the three day Friday through Sunday opening weekend.  It should do very well.
Dawn of the Planet of the Apes runs for 2 hours and 10 minutes.
 As a marker of relative popularity, Transformers 4 has raked in three quarters of a billion dollars worldwide.
Epic movie. Makes me a little more proud of humanity knowing it creates such beautiful pieces of art with such deep self reflection.
Awesome movie no time wasted.
Awesome!!! Just like Star Wars VI and V. Great movie.

Great action drama. This was even better than Rise. The story was very well written and the Apes in this one are way more advanced than in the previous installment. I will definitely be purchasing this on blu ray.

Dawn of the planet of the apes is my favorite movie of the year,I am bias because I am a huge planet of the apes fan but whats not to like about this gripping, emotional science fiction. It is definitely one of the greatest planet of the apes films of all time.

This is definitely a film worth watching. It may be 2+ hours long but I personally didn't even feel the time because the movie was so good. It had me at the edge of my seat from beginning to end. Great movie!
Great sequel to the original! A must watch for any Andy Serkis fan.

This movie is amazing. It's gritty and raw and so full of emotion. It's easy to forget that the apes are CGI, they look so real. I love the eerie feeling I got watching the apes ride horses. I hope this franchise continues because the stories are wonderful and thought provoking. I don't believe that a zombie apocalypse is in our future but apes could certainly take over the world ;-)

A new low in the history of Hollywood filmmaking, The Dawn of the Planet of the Apes has a boringly conventional storyline, "aping" actual US history, namely lots of killing of one group by another. It never ceases to amaze me how American filmmakers can foist this sort of trash onto the public. The movie attempts to depict itself as an epic story of love and war but all the really interesting opportunities are completely lost because the director favours lots of scenes with guns and shooting, which is what Hollywood is really all about anyway. The apes are unconvincing because their culture is more or less a copy of human culture, so although there has been a miraculous development of speech, they have not evolved past the stone age in other respects. The humans of course are still a murderous disorganised mess. This movie really has very few merits at all, its just more of the same.

I've been a fan since the rise of the apes I never thought I would like a series like this but this one is one of my all time top movie series out there dawn of the apes was such a amazing I couldn't believe how good it was right after the movie was over I knew I wanted to buy this and I will such a amazing movie for me this was the movie of the year for me!!!!! hands down
A greatly worked follow-up to Rise of the Planet of the Apes.  I can't wait to see what else this series will bring.
As far as sequels go this one excels expectations. Both Rise of the Planet of the Apes and Dawn of the Planet of the Apes are worthy successors to the Apes throne.
One of the most epic films of the year. A Must Watch. Great Story,Great Characters,great action. Not your average plot.

I've seen all of the Planet of The Apes movies and this is my favorite so far. However, I would suggest that you watch Rise of The Planet of The Apes before watching this one. Everything just comes together very well; the story, the CGI, it's all excellent.

The newly rebooted saga, which began with Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)and continues this month with Dawn of the Planet of the Apes, has captured the spirit and thrill of the original films. Dawn picks up the story 10 years after Rise,where the apes escaped captivity,rampaged along the Golden Gate Bridge,headed up into the hills. Project Nim could be said to have inspired the new reboot of which Dawn is sequel. Rise showed the beginnings of the ape rebellion in which Andy Serkis did a stunning mo-cap performance,displacing Franco as the star. I loved this superb film, directed by Matt Reeves, contracted to do the 3rd film in the rebooted series.

A rule in acting is don'tplay against animals or children(or mo-cap).We have to acknowledge that this computer-filtered form of acting,reveals it in a new light, putting actors playing humans in the shade. They can't compete: this film anthropomorphizes apes more than its predecessor. We see how close apes are to humans. How Serkis' eyes and muscle- movements come through clearly. His slow movements show authority. He taps roots of emotion,gravitas, pathos,solidarity with the ape community,empathy with the human survivors,sentiment with his family group. Apes ride horses,shoot guns,drink alcohol,love,cry,are nostalgic about their childhood,walk upright,speak. They also show similar vices of militarism,aggression. Both species are now vying for dominance.

As leader,Caesar is forced to confront the mistrust of apes as well as the humans,all of whom threaten to destroy each other. When the apes discover a settlement of humans not far from the forest,they are torn between those led by Caesar,who want to help them and those led by Koba(Toby Kebbell) who want to kill them. When communicating with each other they use sign language (which is subtitled),but speak louder in human language when assertive or angry."Apes do not want war", Caesar's first communication uttered to the community of humans from his apesmassed on horseback. A central tenet of ape society is " Ape does not kill ape",however that core principle is later overturned as ape turns on ape,as Koba strives to become leader and kill humans,after shooting Caesar.

Humans are living in post-apocalyptic wretchedness,short of food,fuel,electricity. A virus(wrongly blamed on the apes) has wiped out huge swathes of population. Their leader is Dreyfus(Oldman, the go-to actor for playing authority figures).The humans are also somewhat underwhelming in the film. Malcolm(Jason Clarke) with his partner Ellie(Keri Russell) must figure out how to build their trust to gain access to the dam. Malcolm and Caesar share similar gentleness and ambivalence,mirroring each other's family grouping. The film has rugged action sequences, extraordinary CGI, mo-cap in wild environments,simian teeth-baring,swaying and screeching. Terrifying scenes of people scurrying for safety as invaders round them up;apes on horseback traversing the dark woods or flying through the tree-tops,hunting deer,killing a bear;the mass attack with them riding tanks,blowing up defences.

Mo-cap acting serves animated features up to a computer. The speech acts come in bite-sized chunks," Apes together strong", "Caesar loves humans more than apes".They almost speak like Apaches in old westerns. This is necessary,we are talking about different species. We could be talking about races. In times of intense blood bath in the Middle East, this excellent sequel seems tailor-made to reflect the present conflict between Israelis and Palestinians. The scarred Koba is a scourge of humans, a terrorist leader. Kebell projects malevolence brilliantly. Like Serkis he fuses human and ape. Good sci-fi should hold up a mirror to humanity and reflect our own conflicts, issues and failings back to us through a wildly outrageous premise. Splendidly energising,darker and definitely more cool.

"Dawn of the Planet of the Apes" (2014 release; 130 min.) picks up 10 years from where we left "Rise of the Planet of the Apes". In the movie's opening montage, we learn that during that time, a virus has wiped out much of human kind. leaving only pockets of people here and there. After that, it doesn't take long for the story line to unfold: the apes, still lead by Caesar, live in the forests somewhere north of the Golden Gate Bridge (or what remains of it), and the humans live in San Fran. During a quest to find the dam which could provide power to the city, the humans accidentally bump into the apes, and from there all hell breaks loose. To tell you more of the plot-heavy movie would spoil your viewing experience, you'll just have to see for yourself how it all plays out.

Couple of comments: first and foremost, this movie delivers all the thrills that "Rise" provided, and then raises the bar a couple of notches. The first hour of the movie, set mostly in the forests, reminded me in spirit several times of "Jurassic Park" actually. The second hour of the movie, set mostly in the city, is just about near-perfect action. Second, the performance of Andy Serkis as Caesar the ape has been much lauded, and rightfully so. The opening shot of the movie, an extreme close-up of Serkis' eyes filling the huge movie screen and then zooming out to give his whole face, is just brilliant. Most importantly, Serkis is able to relate to us emotionally what Caesar is going through. Kerri "Felicity" Russell plays one of the humans lead roles, and she looks like she hasn't aged a day in the last 10 years. But the big star of the movie is of course the CGI department, which does a masterful job in creating this planet of the apes. Some of the battle scenes, involving hundreds of apes, are nothing short of eye-popping. Finally, there is a very nice orchestral score, courtesy of composer Michael Giacchino. Somewhere in the movie out of the blue The Band's "The Weight" pops up as well, and it marks for a light moment, however brief...

The movie has been out over a month and I just now went to see it a few days ago this past weekend. The matinee screening where I saw this at was amazingly still very packed, even though this is the 5th weekend the movie is playing. It's a true testament to the wide popularity of this franchise, and "Dawn" in particular. Not surprisingly, a release date for the next sequel has already been announced (July, 2016). I'm looking forward to catching that in 2 years.  Bottom line: if you enjoyed "Rise", you will absolutely LOVE "Dawn of the Planet of the Apes". HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

What an exciting and thrilling blockbuster! I was worried about this film. This was the 8th add on to the Planet of the Apes series, second to the reboots. So this Is a sequel and an eighth movie. I expected that it would feel a bit stretching, but it isn't.
