This second film picks up ten years after the end of the first film - Caesar (Andy Serkis) and his tribe (which has grown exponentially in just a decade) are living a peaceful, family-centered life - their creed is "apes do not kill apes."  When a group of humans wander into their territory, a trigger-happy idiot (Kirk Acevedo) shoots and kills one young ape.  This creates not only the potential for war between the two species, but it's a real threat to Caesar's leadership.  Caesar believes strongly in peace, but his rival, Koba (Toby Kebbell), believes that the only good human is a dead human - this is not surprising considering the amount of torture and experimentation Koba was subjected to by human scientists.  So as much as Caesar struggles to maintain the peace (he's cooperative with the humans, who are trying to restore power to San Francisco through hydraulics), Koba works against him to stir things up.

While DAWN is visually powerful, it lacks the kind of story that made RISE such a provocative film.  The entire plot of DAWN can be summed up as follows:  Caesar tries to keep the peace while Koba lusts for war; the good humans (Jason Clarke's Malcolm and Keri Russell's Ellie) support Caesar, while the bad humans (the aforementioned idiot and Gary Oldman's Dreyfus) prove Koba's point about human nature.  The human characters here are little more than stereotypes.  Malcolm and Ellie care about the environment and their ape cousins, while Dreyfus shouts things like, "They're animals!" and gets everyone practicing with automatic weapons.  We never learn much about any of these people, other than what side they're on.

As for the apes, they're more interesting.  Serkis is fabulous as Caesar, an ape troubled by his own experiences with humans - he clearly loved Will Rodman, the human scientist who raised and protected him in RISE, and Koba is right when he says that Caesar's feelings make it difficult for him to accept the truth about human nature.  But there's very little actual dialogue among the apes - most of them speak only through sign language, with on-screen subtitles.  Only Caesar speaks, and even he uses very few words.  This makes it more difficult to communicate complex ideas, meaning the conflict the film sets up is very basic - Caesar believes it's possible to live in peace with humans; Koba believes it is not.

There's no doubt where this film series is headed - it's called "Planet of the Apes," after all, meaning the apes will be victorious in the final conflict.  I expect the next film (already scheduled for a 2016 release) to give us a version of Armageddon, and Caesar's tribe will finally claim the planet for its own.  But will this new series end where the 1968 classic did, two thousand years in the future, with Charleton Heston's Taylor on that beach staring at the remains of the Statue of Liberty?  That was one of the most powerful film endings I've ever seen, one that impresses me even now, after almost fifty years.  When Heston screamed, "You maniacs!  You blew it all up!," we knew what he was talking about - the human race destroyed itself through senseless war and nuclear weapons.  This new series has a more complicated premise - humans created the intelligent apes in the first place, they also created the virus that decimated humanity, and they will instigate the war that will decide their fate.  But the apes aren't innocent, either.  In DAWN, Koba sets up the initial conflict, and he pushes his people toward a war Caesar is desperate to avoid.  At the end of this film, it's Caesar who must decide how to respond to the coming war, and it's his eyes we see in tight close-up before the final credits.  I found the ending to be the weakest part of the film, since Caesar's ultimate decision makes little sense in terms of his character, but rather feels like the necessary plot device to get us to the next installment.  I loved the 1968 film - I still do.  And I appreciate both RISE and DAWN as compelling films in their own right.  DAWN is a good movie; it just isn't as thought-provoking as either RISE or the 1968 original.  Watch it for Serkis, for the set design, and for Matt Reeves's direction (he will also direct the 2016 film).  And then watch the 1968 film.  That one is a classic for a reason.

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is the sequel to 2011's Rise of the Planet of the Apes. It's a sequel that outshines it's predecessor in every way possible. The characters are believable and have clear motivations throughout the film. There is a great sense of tension throughout the film, and as situations between the humans and the apes escalate you can't help but feel like your holding a rubber band that is on the brink of snapping.

The film is at it's best when the focus is on the titular apes. That's not to say that the human scenes are bad; they're actually really great, I just preferred following their struggle, because they were incredibly engaging characters. The real meat of the film is the interaction between humans and apes, and it is because of everyone's motivations for doing what they do making perfect sense.

Andy Serkis and Toby Kebbell, give amazing performances as Caesar and Koba, while the artists at Weta did a marvelous job at making their characters look believable. The apes' human counterparts Malcom (Clarke) and Dreyfuss (Oldman), are also given moments to shine.

This film is truly one of 2014's best.

Although it is never quite as powerful or electrifying as the film promises it will become " Dawn of the Planet of the Apes " never forgets the intimate and dramatic focus at the heart of both the apes' and the humans' struggle. It lures you into a world that is consistently engrossing from the opening shot which only becomes all the more I incredibly vivid and jaw dropping as the story propels forward. The C.G.I., unlike most occasions of its use, is seamless and gives the apes more dimension than the human characters themselves. It is not as thoughtful or as full of ideas as "Rise of the Planet of the Apes" but it's still captivating and the pace is confident and even throughout. This film, along with "Godzilla" from earlier this Summer,  represents an emphasis on character, drama and story over relentless action (though the few scenes it has of it are remarkably well-made). It's a focus on narrative over hollow style that has crafted two of the best motion pictures this season and a formula I hope Hollywood continues to repeat.

"Dawn of the Planet of the Apes" is an amazing spectacle of cinema! Every single thing about this film works to the nth degree!

The story, about survival, family, and a battle between animal vs. man is highly engaging. The actors, particularly Andy Serkis as Caesar and Toby Kebbell as Koba, the villain, and Nick Thurston as Caesar's son, Blue Eyes, all done with motion capture, they make their performances so human. The music sweeps you away and brings you into a sci-fi world of incredible scope. The human elements are also grat with Malcolm played by Jason Clarke and the other bad guy played by Gary Oldman add more heart, which I feel the apes already brought, but that's just me!

In a nutshell, I loved this movie more than "Rise", which I felt was a good intro to these characters, but this sequel is able to add more depth to the characters and much more. Highly Recommended!

After experiments on chimpanzees infected with the mind-enhancing Simian Flu virus go awry, the chimps escape and the backfiring virus decimates most of the human population. Complete background is available at planetoftheapes.wikia.com: It might be helpful to look over this site before seeing the movie, especially if you're like me and haven't seen the earlier Rise Of The Planet of the Apes. The chimps, along with a minority of gorillas and orangutans, develop a rudimentary civilization of their own, hunting with spears and arrows and riding horse-back. Small contingents of humanity survive, however, and soon a band of apes in the forests near what's left of San Francisco encounters a hold-out of these survivors. There are some attempts to peacefully coexist, but . . . DAWN of the PLANET of the APES ("DPA") is fun, enthralling, carefully filmed, and does a nice job of showing the back-story of the earlier "Planet of the Apes" films of the '70s. It begins as a thoughtful science fiction drama, gradually becoming more of a fast action-driven thriller. Still, I'm sure a thriller is what most people are after here, and I'm not sure how it could have gone any other way. Even in the violent latter portions, there are some touching moments and interesting turnabouts, with excellent special effects and CGI throughout. There are all kinds of potential themes and parallels in this film. The juxtaposed dove/hawk power struggles between the competing chimp alpha males--pragmatic and basically peaceful Caesar versus tragic and embittered Koba--and two human alpha males--conciliatory architect Malcolm versus the more bellicose former Chief of Police Dreyfus--do much to support the story. As in the earlier films, some may find the apes a bit over-idealized with all their noble "Ape not kill ape!" business. Chimps can be quite vicious and are often cannibalistic, but they're supposed to have evolved beyond that here (even though they obviously haven't completely). A few more choice minutes toward the beginning on how the ape society develops, particularly on how the orangutans and gorillas, who take a vague cheap seat to the more numerous and practical-minded chimps, are supposed to fit in would have been a plus. There's one gibbon or monkey sentry shown early-on, but s/he's apparently a loner. A more visible female presence among the apes, something that is completely missing for most of the film, is also sorely needed. Yep, a more diverse ape society would have been great, but I guess you can't expect everything. While it can be fun to analyze and dissect DPA, too much of this is likely to ruin a film that's intended mainly as fairly simple entertainment. All that being said, there's some interesting character development in DPA. Caesar and Koba are particularly fascinating even though the former seems more like a man in a chimp's body than an evolved chimp. Perhaps that's the point: For better or worse, brilliant Caesar was more responsive to the early experiments and became "more like us." Still, why oh why does he speak English even when alone with his fellow chimps? Nevertheless, Andy Serkis does a magnificent job with the voice and everything else he was given in portraying Caesar. The costume design is more problematic. The primary chimps, along with the cute babies (actual chimps?) look quite real, but many of their supporters are less-so. While the orangs and gorillas look real enough, they are a bit bigger-than-life. The humans all look amazingly clean and well-groomed considering the conditions under which they've been living. Still, the human acting is generally good, with some fairly memorable performances by Jason Clarke as Malcolm, Keri Russell as his nurse-wife Ellie, and Kodi Smit-McPhee as Malcolm's son, Alexander. For all its kinks, DPA does an admirable job of showing some truly fantastic situations in the most convincing manner possible, and I'm sure anyone who's enjoyed the other "Planet of the Apes" films will like this one.

A few years ago, Rise of the Planet of the Apes surprised many by reviving the respected, but obviously aging franchise.  Its continuation, Dawn of the Planet of the Apes, is an astonishing and nearly perfect science-fiction adventure film which will again raise the franchise's credibility and presence in the contemporary pop-culture landscape.  Rise is a very solid film with a few superior components, largely of the motion-capture variety, with many demanding an Oscar nomination for Andy Serkis' head-turning digital performance as the intelligent and rebellious ape Caesar.  This second (or eighth) film, which finds Caesar and his forest ape clan threatened by desperate human survivors barely holding on in a ruined San Francisco,  enhances and further explores what resonated with audiences before and represents an enormous overall improvement.  From the dynamic opening (an almost dialogue-free depiction of the apes' woodland existence, from hunting to the seeds of power-play politics) onward, I found myself riveted.  The action is crisp and exciting, blending summer-movie spectacle with a sense of ferocity and menace.  The human/ape interaction, as well as the portrayal of divergent worldviews within both sides, vibrates with genuine and complex moral severity.  The choices have substance.  The antagonistic characters (both human and ape) operate from a place we can comprehend, even if we do not condone their behavior.  The violence is considered and has quantifiable impact.  On the whole, Dawn of the Planet of the Apes can and should be held up as an example of epic-scale American genre cinema at very close to its most taut and thoughtful.

Just saw it in the theater.  WOW.
I sat there in amazement at the depth of the story and power of the imagery in this movie.  Great music.
Just give it time to unfold though...they take a lot of time to give breath to the characters.
Wow. Wow. Wow

In the much anticipated sequel to "Rise of the Planet of the Apes," we find a world almost devoid of human life (due to the ravages of the "Simian Flu"). Heroic Caesar has, in Moses-like fashion, led his kind to the promised land of Muir Woods and established a fledgling community of still-evolving apes (which are mostly chimps and orangutans). Meanwhile, it is revealed that a sizable band of humans survived the plague (back across the bridge in San Francisco) and need power from a hydroelectric generator to sustain what is a bare minimal existence within the confines of a crumbling high-rise. Trouble is, the generator is located in Muir Woods--ape territory. And thus begins the simian struggle for ascendancy to the evolutionary top spot and humanity's last stand to hold on to it.

"Dawn of the Planet of the Apes" is a thoughtful, entertaining sequel in the rebooted series that follows in the vein of the classic 1968 opener. The original had the revolutionary makeup design and novel concept going for it, just like "Dawn" has remarkable CGI battleramas and simian characterization in it's corner. But amazingly, the producers also paid great attention to the script, particularly regarding character and plot development.

All of the main characters (whether simian or human) are very well written; and the actors' performances convey every level of emotion, from love to angst to retribution. And to the writer's credit, some of the apes (particularly Caesar's lieutenant Koba) have flaws that make them as loathsome as their human counterparts. This plot evolution, from the wholly sympathetic role of Caesar and company in "Rise", allows for the series's signature allegory and allusion to shine through. Caesar finds himself dealing with being an administrator, instead of liberator, for much of the movie. That means fighting to uphold the laws "against enemies foreign and domestic" (to borrow from  the human presidential pledge).  Malcolm, Ellie, and Alexander (the heroic human triumvirate) seem to have the toughest battle: Struggling to gather more resources--a sign of rebuilding the infrastructure that once subjugated apes--while trying to build peaceful relations with an ape community that slowly realizes mankind's desperation...and may capitalize upon it at any moment.

Particularly noteworthy are the performances of the movie's villains: Dreyfus (the leader of San Francisco's surviving humans) and ape Koba. Though the designated heaviest of the heavies, Dreyfus is shown mourning the loss of loved ones and willing to allow for negotiations for the use of the hydroelectric generator. But, he also realizes a greater duty to maintain not just electrical power but political power (in a world of growing ape domination). And Koba is justifiably cynical of human intentions (from his mistreatment as a lab test subject in "Rise"). And his excursions into the city prove him to be somewhat correct. These added layers of sympathy (for what are billed as devils) not only attempt to break  from the typical blockbuster movie villain trope, but build an intelligent plot that questions the motives of man and ape and whether any of them are better or worse than the other.

The movie's negatives are few. There should have been more of a female presence (besides Ellie's);  the gorillas seemed to take a back seat to the more prominently-featured chimps and orangutans; and "Dawn" is a bit too localized--that is, there needed to be a more definite view of whether apes were truly on the evolutionary cusp of planetary conquest or just conquest of Northern California (which may come in future episodes).

So while many will be mesmerized by the movie's special effects--the post apocalyptic view of San Francisco alone is worth watching the movie!--Dawn of the Planet of the Apes also delivers a good script and memorable characterizations. Not as memorable as Taylor, Zira, and Dr. Zaius. But "Dawn" is easily one of the best movies in the entire series because it achieves the harmonious blend of both action and drama, entertainment and enlightenment that made the series so special over 40 years ago.

I had very high expectations for Dawn of the Planet of the Apes, especially since I'm such a huge fan of the original films, as well as, the reboot Rise of the Planet of the Apes.  So, Comparing Dawn to Rise, I have to say that Rise was better, but Dawn was still an excellent film that had its moments that I'm sure I'll be thinking about for days to come.  The thing that stands out the most is how well Dawn creates a dystopian future that centers around technology fears, and war.  The bottom line is if you're a Planet of the Apes fan of the previous films, then you will enjoy Dawn.  I'll update this review as soon as I hear news about the special features, but for now go see Dawn.

The Blu-ray release of Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is presented in 1080p with DTS-HD Master Audio 7.1 surround.

Special features include:

Audio Commentary by Matt Reeves
Deleted Scenes with Optional Commentary by Matt Reeves

The World of Dawn
The Ape Community
Move Like an Ape: An Artist s Artist's Medium
Weta and Dawn
The Fight for a New Dawn
Four Galleries

Coming off the heals of one of the most talked about reboots in 2011s Rise of the Planet of the Apes comes a movie filled with emotion and heart. With Rupert Wyatt not returning to direct, newcomer Matt Reeves (Cloverfield, Let Me In) takes his chair in delivering what is a cinematic masterpiece. Its years after the ALZ virus had spread killing most of the human population; while Cesar and his army of apes survives in the forest and in hopes of building a future. Peace may not last very long, however, as an altercation takes place between humans and apes that threatens war and a future for all.

As earth lays in ruins from the virus outbreak we see what happens when apes and humans have to depend on their respective species. Returning to play Cesar is Andy Serkis who stands strong with his character as he tries to bring balance to a world that can no longer have trust. When the apes discover live humans after so many years its hard to imagine who is a real threat. Brilliant writing from Rick Jaffa, Amanda Silver, and others helped to incorporate realism into the film that brought conflict amongst the humans and Cesars family.

One of the survivors in Malcolm, played by Jason Clarke, tries to keep the peace between the apes and his colony that even his own people blame the apes for the extinction of man. There lies this underlining truth that humans were responsible for the outbreak; yet the apes having been tested are portrayed as the real enemy. The apes see humans as violent beings who don't know any better as they continue to hunt and kill living things with guns and weapons. All of these dilemmas are balanced so that we can sense the struggles between both sides and can relate to the characters.

There were great moments during the battles; especially during the final act when apes were confronting apes and humans confronting humans. Watching them side by side were complimentary to the themes of the film where loyalty and trust were tested. The Cesar and Koba story was the center piece of the movie as one had faith in humans, while the other carries scars from his past. One cant help but feel for the other as both have reasons that make the other an enemy to oneself.

All around the performances were amazing, while Cesar stole the show. The pacing of the film was perfect as you never felt the movie dragged or was running out of material. True story telling that had a slow build to a climatic ending. There were moments of suspense and shock that when it happens it leaves you wondering what is there left to offer for the survivors and all those forced to co-exist. The opening sequence summed up the events in the first film and then bringing us to the present with Cesar commanding. Minor criticisms at best with most dealing with plot details.

In a turn of events, Matt Reeves delivered an amazing film that stands next to its predecessor; if not better. From dialogue to moral and internal struggles gives Dawn of the Planet of the Apes a rise above the rest. Of a year filled with sequels, Dawn is a contender for the top spot and may be a true test for others to follow.

By now we all recognize that Hollywood is driven by the big money and bigger spectacle that sequels provide, with narrative need probably way down the totem pole when considering such follow-ups. As we've just endured the third unnecessary Transformers sequel, such things can prove to be a little depressing, and there was some concern that Dawn of the Planet of the Apes could be just another soulless sequel churned out by the system with pumped up CGI and no real heart. But the film, a technical and thematic marvel crafted by Matt Reeves, is not only exciting in the way we all want summer blockbusters to be, it improves on its predecessor in just about every way.

That's not a knock on Rise of the Planet of the Apes, a film that far exceeded expectations largely by giving in to its sci-fi B-movie roots. It worked as a warning to man's selfish meddling in the ways of nature and as a campy action flick about rampaging apes. 'Dawn' is considerably more serious but let's be honest here, this isn't the "Planet of the Apes and those Pesky Humans' series. We expect things to get a little dark along the way and probably won't turn out so well for our side. Action and violence, of which there are plenty of both, doesn't simply occur for the sake of momentary thrills. Every life-or-death decision is weighed, measured, and has real significance to the future of two opposing species.

Building on the sturdy foundation laid by the prior film, this one moves forward in time ten years after the human population has nearly been eradicated by the Simian Flu. Caesar (Andy Serkis, and let's just say the man deserves an Oscar by now) is no longer the young, genetically evolved ape we saw before. Now he's the leader of a tribe, and more than that he's got a wife (Judy Greer) and young son, Blue Eyes (Nick Thurston), relying on him. Like any leader, Caesar has those who are loyal and some like the badly-scarred Koba (Toby Kebbell), who claim loyalty but have their own motivations. The rules of their society are pretty simple, with the biggest rule scrawled in chalk, "Ape no kill ape". Humans haven't been spotted in what remains of San Francisco in years, so when a small pocket of them are encountered and it ends in bloodshed, some of Caesar's followers start sounding the drumbeat for war.

Screenwriters Mark Bomback, Rick Jaffa, and Amanda Silver draw obvious but resonant parallels between Caesar and Malcolm (Jason Clarke), a leading voice amongst the humans with his own son (Kodi Smit-McPhee) and lover (Keri Russell) to take care of. Unlike some of the others in their group, neither Malcolm or Caesar wants a battle, recognizing that a full scale war could destroy them all. But the humans need power to rebuild civilization, and the only source is on the apes' home turf. Without it, people have essentially reverted back to a primal state and their desperate, battle-ready leader Dreyfus (Gary Oldman, in Commissioner Gordon mode) is ready to do anything to change that.

Analogies to race relations or the ongoing conflict in the Middle East are clear but never beaten to death. It's far more concerned with common themes of loyalty, family, and betrayal, all of which are approached with sincerity and intelligence. When Caesar becomes father to a newborn child, we recognize how the stakes have been elevated and why he makes certain choices. Of course, we also know that whatever he decides it will end up with hundreds of digital apes swinging from power lines and firing machine guns from horseback. How would you like to be a normal animal in a world of evolved chimps? That must really suck. Anyway, when monkey mayhem ensues it's quite the computer-generated showcase. Reeves has done some spectacular digital effects work before, most notably in the monster flick Cloverfield. But let's not forget he also directed the superior vampire remake, Let Me In, and 'Dawn' impressively combines pot boiling thrills with moments of sheer horror. Comedy is sparse but there are a few moments of monkey mockery that are worth a laugh. They tend to end with somebody dying but they're funny for a time.

What more is there to say about Andy Serkis' performance capture work at this point? The emotion he's able to wring is truly exceptional, and I've personally come around to thinking we need a special category for honoring what he's so consistently been able to do. One only wishes the humans had more to work with. Clarke makes the most of a character that is basically just meant to play a lesser version of Caesar. Oldman is never given a chance to be the firebrand his character would seem to demand. But as noted before, this is 'Planet of the Apes', and so they get the bulk of the character focus. Where 'Rise' was mostly a movie about humans, we're clearly meant to land on the side of the apes now and it feels a little counter-intuitive at first.

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is a deeply intelligent, wildly entertaining sequel that proves the summer blockbuster is capable of evolution, too.
